{{legend2|magenta| (172034) 2001 WR1}}{{·}}{{legend2|RoyalBlue|[[Earth]]}}{{·}}{{legend2|DarkRed|[[Mars]]}} {{·}}{{legend2|Yellow|[[Sun]]}}]] '''{{mp|(172034) 2001 WR|1}}''', provisional designation ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'', is a sub-kilometer [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Amor asteroid|Amor group]], approximately {{convert|650|m|ft|abbr=off|sigfig=2|sp=us}} in diameter. The [[S-type asteroid]] has been identified as a potential flyby target of the ''[[Hayabusa2]]'' mission. It was discovered on 17 November 2001, by astronomers with the [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research]] at the [[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site]] near Socorro, New Mexico, in the United States. The asteroid has a [[rotation period]] of 8.0 hours and possibly an elongated shape. It remains unnamed since its [[Minor planet designation|numbering]] in December 2007. == Orbit and classification == ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' is an [[Amor asteroid]] – a subgroup of near-Earth asteroids that approach the orbit of Earth from beyond, but do not cross it. The object orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.02–1.54 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 17 months (527 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 1.28 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.20 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 25[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with its first observation in February 1953, more than 48 years prior to its official discovery observation at Socorro. The [[precovery]] was taken at [[Palomar Observatory]] and published by the [[Digitized Sky Survey]]. === Close encounters === ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' has an Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] of {{convert |0.0747 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}} which corresponds to 29.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. In September 1926, it approached Earth to {{convert |0.1496 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}}, its closest approach of all close encounters since 1900. Only in September 2199, it will approach Earth at a similar distance of {{convert |0.1514 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}}. == ''Hayabusa2'' mission == ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' is currently the prime target of the ''[[Hayabusa2]]'' mission for a [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] planned to occur on 27 June 2023. When the spacecraft returns to Earth and delivers the sample capsule in December 2020, it is expected to retain 30 kg of [[xenon]] propellant, which can be used to extend its service and flyby new targets to explore. == Numbering and naming == This [[minor planet]] was [[Minor planet designation|numbered]] by the [[Minor Planet Center]] on 24 December 2007 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 61443}}). As of 2018, it has not been [[List of named minor planets (numerical)|named]]. == Physical characteristics == ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' has been characterized as a common, stony [[S-type asteroid]]. === Rotation period === In March 2018, a rotational [[lightcurve]] of ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' was obtained from [[Photometry (astronomy)|photometric]] observations by [[Brian D. Warner|Brian Warner]] at the Palmer Divide Station {{Obscode|U82}} in California. Lightcurve analysis gave a [[rotation period]] of {{val|8.0475|0.0003}} hours with a brightness amplitude of 0.95 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3]]}}), indicative of a non-spherical shape.{{efn|name=lightcurveplot-Warner}} === Diameter and albedo === According to the survey carried out by the [[NEOWISE]] mission of NASA's [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]], ''{{mp|2001 WR|1}}'' has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.34 and measures 0.63 and 0.66 kilometers in diameter, respectively. The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes a standard albedo for a stony asteroid of 0.20 and calculates a diameter of 0.818 kilometers based on an [[absolute magnitude]] of 17.8. == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name=lightcurveplot-Warner|1=[http://www.planetarysciences.org/plots/BDW/172034_2001WR1_20180221.PNG Lightcurve plot of (172034) 2001 WR1] from Feb/Mar 2018 by [[Brian D. Warner]] at the Palmer Divide Observatory {{Obscode|U82}}. Rotation period {{val|8.0475|0.0003}} hours with a brightness amplitude of {{val|0.95|0.03}} mag. Quality code is 3. Summary figures at the [http://www.planetarysciences.org CS3] and [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=172034%7C2001+WR1 LCDB].}} }} == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2018-05-21 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 172034 (2001 WR1) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2172034;cad=1 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 22 September 2018}} {{cite web |title = 172034 (2001 WR1) |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=172034 |accessdate = 22 September 2018}} {{cite web |title = MPC/MPO/MPS Archive |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/MPCArchive_TBL.html |accessdate = 22 September 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid (172034) 2001 WR1 |work = Small Bodies Data Ferret |url = https://sbntools.psi.edu/ferret/SimpleSearch/results.action?targetName=172034 |accessdate = 22 September 2018}} {{Cite journal |first1 = Bruno Victorino |last1 = Sarli |first2 = Yuichi |last2 = Tsuda |date = September 2017 |title = Hayabusa 2 extension plan: Asteroid selection and trajectory design |url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?doi=10.1016/j.actaastro.2017.05.016 |journal = Acta Astronautica |volume = 138 |pages = 225–232 |bibcode = 2017AcAau.138..225S |doi = 10.1016/j.actaastro.2017.05.016 |access-date= 22 September 2018}} {{cite web |title = LCDB Data for (172034) |publisher = Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB) |url = http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=172034%7C |accessdate = 22 September 2018}} {{cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = A. On 18 December 1963 a number of students from [[Ghana]] and other African countries organized a protest on [[Moscow]]'s [[Red Square]] in response to the alleged murder of medical student Edmund Assare-Addo. The number of participants was reported at 500–700,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1963/12/19/page/4/article/500-african-students-riot-in-red-square|title=500 AFRICAN STUDENTS RIOT IN RED SQUARE|date=December 19, 1963|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=28 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="DI">{{cite web | url =http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=DIL19631221.2.11#| title = Russia Issues Warning|publisher =''[[Daily Illini]]''|date=21 December 1963| accessdate =15 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="cairn">{{cite web | url =http://www.cairn.info/zen.php?ID_ARTICLE=CMR_471_0033| title =Death of an African Student in Moscow|publisher =CAIRN.info|author=Julie Hessler| accessdate =15 July 2014}}</ref> but according to the Ghanaian physician Edward Na, who participated in the events, there were at most 150 protesters.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/russian/russia/2010/02/100204_peoples_friendship_lumumba.shtml| script-title=ru:Они учились в СССР |author=Лина Розовская|publisher =[[BBC]]|language=Russian| accessdate =15 July 2014}}</ref> The ambassador of Ghana in the [[Soviet Union]] [[John Banks Elliott]] requested a [[militsiya]] protection of the Ghanaian embassy.<ref name="DI"/>
This was the first recorded political protest on Red Square since the late 1920s.<ref name="cairn"/>
==Background== Edmund Assare-Addo was a 29-year-old student of the Kalinin Medical Institute. His body was found in a stretch of wasteland along a country road leading to the [[Moscow Ring Road]].<ref name="cairn"/> African students alleged that he was knifed<ref name="DI"/> by a Soviet man because Assare-Addo courted a Russian girl.<ref name="bbc"/> The African students based their allegation on the unlikelihood of a student venturing into that remote place.<ref name="bbc"/> The Soviet authorities stated that Assare-Addo froze to death in a snow while being drunk. According to the [[autopsy]], performed by Soviet medics with two advanced medical students from Ghana as observers, the death was "an effect of cold in a state of alcohol-induced [[stupor]]".<ref name="cairn"/> No signs of physical trauma were found, with the possible exception of a small scar on the neck.<ref name="cairn"/>
Discussing the incident<!--the death, or the protest?--> with Soviet officials, Elliot indicated the Western embassies in Moscow ("the U.S., England, France, the FRG, or even Holland") as the probable instigators of the incident.<ref name="cairn"/> Elliot went so far as to suggest that students who "behaved poorly" and "skipped class" should be expelled from the Soviet Union.<ref name="cairn"/> Before the students' march to the Red Square Elliott alleged that the students broke into the Ghanaian embassy and damaged furniture and pictures.<ref name="DI"/>
==Protest== {{wikisource|Memorandum to the Soviet Government from African Students in the Soviet Union}} The protesters were African students studying in Soviet universities and institutes. Having assembled on the morning of 18 December 1963, they wrote a memorandum to present to Soviet authorities. The protesters carried placards with slogans "Moscow – center of discrimination", "Stop killing Africans!" and "Moscow, a second [[Alabama]]", while shouting in English, Russian, and French.<ref name="cairn"/> The protesters marched to the [[Spasskaya Tower|Spasskiye Gates]] of the [[Kremlin]], where they posed for photographs and gave interviews to the Western correspondents.<ref name="cairn"/> The Soviet [[Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union|TASS]] news agency responded with a statement: "It is to be regretted that the meetings of the Ghanaian students which began in connection with their claims to the embassy of their country resulted in the disturbance of public order in Moscow streets. It is quite natural that this is resented by the Russian people".<ref name="DI"/>
On 20 December, the students returned to classes and militsiya ceased the protection of the Ghanaian embassy.<ref name="DI"/>

{{Infobox convention | name = Aussiecon, the 33rd World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Southern Cross Hotel | location = [[Melbourne]] | country = Australia | first = August 14–17, 1975 | last = | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 606 | website = }} The '''33rd World Science Fiction Convention''', called '''Aussiecon''', was held in [[Melbourne]], Australia, August 14–17, 1975, at the Southern Cross Hotel. The guests of honour were [[Ursula K. Le Guin]] (pro), [[Susan Wood Glicksohn|Susan Wood]] (fan), [[Mike Glicksohn]] (fan), and [[Donald Tuck]] (Australian). Aussiecon was significant in the development of cohesive Australian activity around science fiction and fantasy fandom. The chairman was Robin Johnson. The toastmaster was [[John Bangsund]]. Total attendance was 606. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[The Dispossessed]]'' by [[Ursula K. Le Guin]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[A Song for Lya]]" by [[George R. R. Martin]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Adrift Just Off the Islets of Langerhans|Adrift Just Off the Islets of Langerhans: Latitude 38° 54′ N, Longitude 77° 00′ 13″ W]]" by [[Harlan Ellison]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[The Hole Man]]" by [[Larry Niven]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[Young Frankenstein]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Ben Bova]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Frank Kelly Freas]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Amateur Magazine|Best Amateur Magazine]]: ''[[The Alien Critic]]'', edited by [[Richard E. Geis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Richard E. Geis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[William Rotsler|Bill Rotsler]] ===Other awards=== * [[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: [[Donald A. Wollheim]] as "the fan who has done everything" * Special Award: [[Walt Lee]] for ''[[Reference Guide to Fantastic Films]]'' * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[P. J. Plauger]] * [[Gandalf Award|Gandalf Grand Master Award]]: [[Fritz Leiber]] ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[World Science Fiction Society]] *[[World Science Fiction Convention]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= }} == External links == * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1975 NESFA.org: 1975 convention notes] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[32nd World Science Fiction Convention]]

Outraged Greek youth has taken its lead from the Arab spring and Spanish protests over unemployment.}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13830466 |title=Greece crisis: Revolution in the offing? |date=19 June 2011|publisher=BBC |accessdate=6 July 2011|quote=Inspired by the Arab uprisings, they have dug in to oppose further spending cuts in exchange for a second bail-out by the EU and IMF.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110708053420/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13830466| archivedate= 8 July 2011| deadurl= no}} | image = [[Image:2010-2011 Greek protests collage.png|300px]] | caption = A police officer flees rock throwers; a crowd assembles peacefully in front of Parliament | date = 5 May 2010 – 18 October 2012 | place = [[Greece]] | coordinates = | causes = Unemployment, inflation, corruption, [[Greek financial crisis|2010–2011 Greek debt crisis]], [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] presence in the country, harsh [[austerity measures]] with welfare cuts, [[bipartidism]], [[particracy]], [[democracy deficit]] | goals = | result = | methods = Demonstrations, strike action, [[sit-in]]s, occupations, rioting, [[civil disobedience]], [[police violence]] | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | injuries = 28–29 June 2011: over 270{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173486/nuhta-edasis-sto-sudagma/ |script-title=el:Νέα ένταση και κυκλοφοριακό χάος |language=Greek |accessdate=29 June 2011}}

5 April 2012 : 1 (Marios Lolos){{cite web |url=http://news247.gr/eidiseis/koinonia/marios_lwlos_to_xtuphma_htan_dolofoniko.1727739.html |title=Μάριος Λώλος: Το χτύπημα ήταν δολοφονικό |accessdate=22 June 2012}} | fatalities = 5 May 2010: 3
20 October 2011: 1
4 April 2012 : 1
18 October 2012 : 1 | notes = }} {{Anti-austerity movement in the European Union}} The '''anti-austerity movement in [[Greece]]''' involves a series of demonstrations and [[general strike]]s that took place across the country. The events, which began on 5 May 2010, were provoked by plans to cut public spending and raise taxes as [[austerity measure]]s in exchange for a {{Nowrap|€110 billion}} bail-out, aimed at solving the [[Greek government-debt crisis]]. Three people were killed on 5 May in one of the largest demonstrations in Greece [[Athens Polytechnic Uprising|since 1973]]. On {{Start date|2011|5|25|df=y}}, anti-austerity activists organised by the [[Direct Democracy Now!]] movement, known as the '''Indignant Citizens Movement''' ({{lang-el|Κίνημα Αγανακτισμένων Πολιτών}}, ''Kínima Aganaktisménon-Politón''), started demonstrating in major cities across Greece. This second wave of demonstrations proved different from the years before{{cite web|url= http://www.culanth.org/fieldsights/70-the-movement-and-the-movement-of-syntagma-square |author= Dalakoglou Dimitris |title= The Movement and the "Movement" of Syntagma Square |publisher=Cultural Anthropology |year= 2012 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.koutipandoras.gr/?p=7205 |script-title=el:Εκπομπή: Ο δρόμος (για την πλατεία) είχε την δική του ιστορία |language=Greek |date=13 June 2011|publisher=koutipandoras.gr |accessdate=7 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110717085333/http://www.koutipandoras.gr/?p=7205| archivedate= 17 July 2011| deadurl= no}} in that they were not partisan{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170468/oi-aganaktismenoi-diadilonoun-stis-ellinikes-poleis-/ |title=Στα χνάρια των Ισπανών αγανακτισμένων (On the footsteps of the Spanish 'indignados') |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} and began through peaceful means.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170337/aganaktismenoi-sto-sudagma/ |script-title=el:Αγανακτισμένοι στο Σύνταγμα |language=Greek |date=24 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=7 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230601/http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170337/aganaktismenoi-sto-sudagma/| archivedate= 17 July 2011| deadurl= no}} Some of the events later turned violent, particularly in the capital city of [[Athens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/866478-violent-anti-cut-riots-in-greece-spark-coalition-talks |title=Violent anti-cut riots in Greece spark coalition talks |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=15 June 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usamarketnews.com/featured/3761/greece-anxiety-increases-us-stocks-ends-lower-on-wednesday-trading.html |title=Greece Anxiety Increases: US Stocks Ends Lower on Wednesday Trading « USA Market News |publisher=Usamarketnews.com |date=16 June 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13787323 |title=BBC News – Greek PM George Papandreou to unveil new cabinet |publisher=BBC |date=16 June 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110617202255/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13787323| archivedate= 17 June 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41734011/ns/world_news-europe/t/greek-riot-police-protesters-clash-during-crippling-strike/ |title=Greek riot police, protesters clash during strike – World news – Europe |publisher=MSNBC |date=23 February 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}} Inspired by the [[anti-austerity protests in Spain]], these demonstrations were organised entirely using [[social networking site]]s, which earned it the nickname "May of Facebook".{{cite web |url= http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=11424&subid=2&pubid=63092999 |title=Ο Μάης του Facebook και με ομπρέλες |publisher=ethnos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2010}} The demonstrations and square sit-ins were officially ended when municipal police removed demonstrators from [[Thessaloniki]]'s [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]] square on 7 August 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=138427 |title=Απομακρύνθηκαν οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" από τον Λευκό Πύργο |publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=9 August 2011}} On 29 June 2011, violent clashes occurred between the [[riot police]] and activists as the Greek parliament voted to accept the EU's austerity requirements. Incidents of [[police brutality]] were reported by international media such as the [[BBC]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[CNN iReport]] and ''[[The New York Times]]'', as well as by academic research{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/1515683/The_Irregularities_of_Violence_in_Athens|title=Beyond Spontaneity|website=www.academia.edu|access-date=11 April 2016}} and organisations [[Amnesty International]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13960947 |title=Greece passes key austerity vote |publisher=BBC |accessdate=29 June 2011|date=29 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110630043411/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13960947| archivedate= 30 June 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2011/jun/29/greece-austerity-vote-demonstrations#block-35 |title=Greece austerity vote and demonstrations – Wednesday 29 June 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=1 July 2011|first1=Haroon |last1=Siddique |first2=David |last2=Batty |date=29 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629112740/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/jun/29/greece-austerity-vote-demonstrations| archivedate= 29 June 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/01/greek-police-investigation-protest-violence |title=Greek police face investigation after protest violence |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=3 July 2011|first=Helena |last=Smith |date=1 July 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/tear-gas-fired-greek-police-clash-athens-protesters-2011-06-29 |title=TEAR GAS FIRED AS GREEK POLICE CLASH WITH ATHENS PROTESTERS |publisher=amnesty.org |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/greece-urged-not-use-excessive-force-during-protests-2011-06-16 |title=GREECE URGED NOT TO USE EXCESSIVE FORCE DURING PROTESTS |publisher=amnesty.org |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-628589?ref=feeds%2Foncnn |title=Back when peaceful demonstrations in Greece were massive and meaningful... |publisher=CNN |accessdate=3 July 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/30/world/europe/30athens.html?_r=1&ref=policebrutalityandmisconduct |title=Violent Clashes in the Streets of Athens |work=The New York Times |accessdate=3 July 2011|first1=Rachel |last1=Donadio |first2=Scott |last2=Sayare |date=29 June 2011}} The Athens Prosecutor agreed to an investigation into accusations of excessive use of tear gas, as well as the alleged use of other expired and carcinogenic chemical substances. {{As of|2011}} the investigation is under way.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173682/paremvasi-tis-eisaggelias-protodikon-gia-ta-himika-sta-epeisodia/ |script-title=el:Παρέμβαση της Εισαγγελίας Πρωτοδικών για τα χημικά στα επεισόδια |publisher=skai.gr |language=Greek |accessdate=30 June 2011}} ==Background of the 2010 events== {{Greek economic crisis}} {{further|Greek government-debt crisis|Economy of Greece#2010–2017 government debt crisis}} In the early to mid-2000s, the government took advantage of Greece's strong economy by running a large deficit. As the world economy cooled in the late 2000s, Greece was hit hard because its main industries—[[Greek Merchant Navy|shipping]] and [[tourism in Greece|tourism]]—were sensitive to changes in the business cycle. As a result, the country's debt began to pile up rapidly. In early 2010 policy makers{{who|date=November 2011}} suggested that emergency bailouts might be necessary. On 5 March 2010, the [[Hellenic Parliament]] passed the cost-cutting Economy Protection Bill. On 23 April, the Greek government requested that a bailout package offered by the [[European Union]] and the [[International Monetary Fund]] be activated. The funds were expected to be available quickly, but it was unclear if they would be activated before a crucial 19 May debt rollover. On 27 April, [[Standard & Poor's]] cut the country's main debt rating to BB+ ("junk" status), increasing concern that a [[Default (finance)|default]] might occur.{{cite news|title= Cuts to Debt Rating Stir Anxiety in Europe |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/business/global/28drachma.html |work=The New York Times |author=Jack Ewing and Jack Healy |date=27 April 2010|accessdate=6 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100503034602/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/business/global/28drachma.html| archivedate= 3 May 2010| deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/markets/sp-downgrades-greek-debt-to-junk/story-e6frg91o-1225859110788 |title= S&P downgrades Greek debt to junk |author=Katie Martin and Terence Roth |publisher=Dow Jones Newswires |date=28 April 2010|accessdate=6 May 2010}} ===Austerity measures=== On 1 May, Prime Minister [[George Papandreou (junior)|George Papandreou]] announced a [[Third austerity package (Greece)|fourth round of austerity measures]] by the Greek government, described as "unprecedented".{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf |title= The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF |author=Helena Smith |date=9 May 2010|accessdate=10 May 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100510014536/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf| archivedate= 10 May 2010| deadurl= no}} These include more public sector pay cuts, pension reductions, new taxes on company profits, an increase on luxury and [[sin tax]]es, and an increase of the [[value added tax]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8655711.stm|title=Greece police tear gas anti-austerity protesters|date=1 May 2010|publisher=BBC News }}{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gr/news/article.asp?lngEntityID=1132263&lngDtrID=251|title=Fourth raft of new measures|language=Greek|publisher=[[In.gr]] |date=2 May 2010|accessdate=5 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100505125922/http://www.in.gr/news/article.asp?lngEntityID=1132263&lngDtrID=251| archivedate= 5 May 2010| deadurl= no}} The proposed changes, which aim to save {{Nowrap|€30 billion}} through 2012, represent the biggest government overhaul within a single generation. The cuts are in line with the EU-[[International Monetary Fund]] loan proposals, which demand that Greece liberalise its economy.{{cite web |url=http://ametroepeia.pblogs.gr/2011/11/o-kybos-errifthh-alea-jacta-est-and-shit-has-hit-the-fan.html|title=wrath of the People|publisher=Mike Kamateros}} They helped Greece reach a loan agreement, announced on 2 May, for an immediate {{Nowrap|€45 billion}} in loans (with a 5% interest for the most part, provided by the EU), with additional funds available in the future.{{cite news|title = Greece Accepts Terms of EU-Led Bailout, 'Savage' Cuts (Update2) – Bloomberg.com | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=a9f8X9yDMcdI&pos=1 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=3 May 2010|accessdate=7 May 2010|author=Flavia Krause-Jackson and Gabi Thesing}}{{cite web|title = EU puts positive spin on Greek rescue|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/08a87e4e-55c4-11df-b835-00144feab49a.html|work=Financial Times|date=2 May 2010|accessdate=2 May 2010|first=Kerin|last=Hope| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100504203836/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/08a87e4e-55c4-11df-b835-00144feab49a.html| archivedate= 4 May 2010| deadurl= no}} The total value of the loans was expected to be in the {{Nowrap|€110 billion}} range. Papandreou submitted the bill to Parliament on 4 May. The Hellenic Parliament was expected to vote on the proposed austerity measures on 6 May. [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]], the conservative minority party, vowed to vote against the bill, but the bill was expected to pass because of the [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]]'s large 160-seat advantage in Parliament. The government has pleaded with demoralised staff not to retire, fearing that a surge in benefits requests could further drain the public treasury. In separate votes on 29 and 30 June, Parliament approved the austerity measures.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-30/papandreou-wins-enough-votes-to-pass-greek-budget-bill-ensuring-bailout.html|title=Papandreou Wins Vote on Second Greek Austerity Bill in Bid for More EU Aid|last1=Weeks|first1=Natalie|last2=Bensasson|first2=Bensasson|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=30 June 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/30/greece-minister-eurogroup-idUSATH00622820110630|title=Greek finance minister welcomes austerity bill approval|last=Maltezeu|first=Renee|agency=Reuters|date=30 June 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}} ===Relationship to the 2008 Greek riots=== The [[2008 Greek riots]] started on 6 December 2008, when Alexandros Grigoropoulos ({{lang-el|Αλέξανδρος Γρηγορόπουλος}}), a 15-year-old student, was killed by two policemen{{cite news |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_politics_100033_13/06/2009_108067|title=POLICE TRIAL Two indicted over teen shooting |publisher=Kathimerini}} in the [[Exarcheia]] district of central [[Athens]]. While the unrest was triggered by the shooting incident, commentators{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/3073023/The_Crisis_Before_The_Crisis_|title=The Crisis Before "The Crisis"|website=www.academia.edu|access-date=11 April 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/12/08/explainer.greece.riots/index.html | title=Explainer: Why is there unrest in Greece? | publisher=CNN | date=10 December 2008| accessdate=22 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081217115647/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/12/08/explainer.greece.riots/index.html| archivedate= 17 December 2008| deadurl= no}} described the reactions as expressing deeper causes, especially a widespread feeling of frustration in the younger generation about the economic problems of the country (partly as a result of the [[economic crisis of 2008|global economic crisis]]), a rising unemployment rate among young people and a perception of general inefficiency and corruption in Greek state institutions.{{ citation | url= https://www.academia.edu/3073023/The_Crisis_Before_The_Crisis_| title= The Crisis before "The Crisis": Violence and Urban Neoliberalizationin Athens | author= Dalakoglou Dimitris| publisher=Social Justice |date=2013 }}{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12756043&fsrc=rss | title=Behind the protests spreading across Greece | publisher=Economist | accessdate=12 December 2008| date=9 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081215025132/http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12756043&fsrc=rss| archivedate= 15 December 2008| deadurl= no}}{{cite news | url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/12/11/europe/greece.php | title=In Greece, a crisis decades in the making |work=International Herald Tribune | date=11 December 2008| accessdate=12 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081212040015/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/12/11/europe/greece.php| archivedate= 12 December 2008| deadurl= no}} Related sporadic protests continued into 2011 and beyond. ==2010 protests== ===Before 5 May 2010=== On May Day, there were protest marches in [[Athens]] and [[Thessaloniki]], by many unions, left-wing, anarchist and communist party supporters. Violent clashes broke out when riot police were sent out to contain the protestors. On 4 May, members of the [[Communist Party of Greece]] broke into the [[Acropolis of Athens]] and hung banners: "Peoples of Europe Rise Up".{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ynews/ynews_wl1925|title=In Photos: Greek protesters storm the Acropolis|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=4 May 2010}} ===5 May 2010 strike and demonstrations=== In response to the proposed spending cuts and tax increases, a nationwide strike was called for 5 May. Starting at midnight, aeroplane, train, and ferry traffic in and out of the country ceased. Schools, some hospitals, and many private businesses were closed. The demonstrations are seen by some as the most widespread since the end of the [[Greek military junta of 1967–1974]].{{cite news|title= Greek bailout: Athens burns – and crisis strikes at heart of the EU |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/05/greek-bailout-economic-crisis-deaths |author=Helena Smith |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=5 May 2010|accessdate=7 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100506032545/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/05/greek-bailout-economic-crisis-deaths| archivedate= 6 May 2010| deadurl= no}} An estimated 100,000 people marched through Athens, with some estimates stretching to 500,000. As protests gained momentum, a large group tried to storm the parliament building in [[Syntagma Square]] in Athens, where they scuffled with police, causing some of the [[Presidential Guard (Greece)|Presidential Guard]] to flee from the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]]. The protesters accused members of parliament of being "thieves". Riot police were able to push the crowds back with [[tear gas]], [[flash bomb]]s and [[smoke bomb]]s. Nearby buildings, including a finance ministry building, were set on fire. Prime Minister George Papandreou responded "Nobody has the right to violence and particularly violence that leads to murder. Violence breeds violence." [[File:Outside MARFIN bank.png|thumb|People paying their respects to the memory of the people who died on 5 May.]] Protesters set fire to a [[Marfin Investment Group|Marfin Bank]] branch on [[Stadiou Street]] with [[Molotov cocktail]]s; witnesses said that protestors marching past the bank ignored the employees' cries for help, while others chanted [[anti-capitalist]] slogans. Most of the bank's employees managed to escape the burning building, but two employees who jumped from the second-story balcony were injured and two women and a man were found dead after the fire was extinguished. It was reported that fire crews had difficulty reaching the scene because of demonstrations moving through the area. The victims died of [[asphyxiation]] from toxic fumes when they were unable to escape from a roof exit that was blocked. They had gone to work despite the general strike over fears of losing their jobs.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf |location=London |work=The Guardian | title=The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF | first=Helena | last=Smith | date=9 May 2010}} They have been identified as Paraskevi Zoulia, 35, Angeliki Papathanasopoulou, 32 (who was four months pregnant), and Epaminondas Tsakalis, 36.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/in-athens-the-day-was-calm-then-came-night-1965609.html |title=In Athens the day was calm. Then came night |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=7 May 2010|accessdate=7 May 2010| first1=John | last1=Lichfield | first2=Menelaos | last2=Tzafalias| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100508201535/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/in-athens-the-day-was-calm-then-came-night-1965609.html| archivedate= 8 May 2010| deadurl= no}} Papandreou called the incident a "murderous act". [[Michalis Chrysohoidis]], the [[Minister for the Protection of the Citizen]], declared that "today is a black day for democracy...undemocratic forces have [latched on to] a peaceful demonstration of workers and now petrol bombs have killed three of our citizens and put an immediate danger to the lives of others." He also stated that "the killers will be caught and punished accordingly". Police started a widespread search, with the help of closed-circuit television footage to detect and arrest the suspects. The police blamed "hooded youth" for the incident, while one protestor who spoke to BBC blamed police brutality for the escalation of violence which was started when protestors threw [[Molotov cocktail]]s at police; the police responded with pepper spray and tear gas. In response to the incident, the [[Greek Federation of Bank Employees' Unions]] blamed bank management for inadequate safety measures in the building and called for strike action. Elsewhere in Athens, some demonstrators threw rocks, bottles, and pieces of marble at the police. Numerous trash bins were lit on fire. Some broke windows, threw petrol bombs, and committed other acts of vandalism. Other protesters set up barricades and burned cars. Across Athens, at least 12 people were injured, and more than 70 people were detained for questioning.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/05/05/greece.strikes/|title=Three dead as Greek strike grows violent|publisher=[[CNN International]]|accessdate=7 May 2010|quote=and more than 70 were brought in for questioning by Wednesday evening | date=5 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100508141503/http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/05/05/greece.strikes/| archivedate= 8 May 2010| deadurl= no}} In [[Thessaloniki]], 37 people were arrested as a result of the protests. ====Aftermath of protest of 5 May==== On 5 and 6 May 2010, the Hellenic Parliament passed the proposed austerity measures, claiming they show the Greek government's commitment to tackling its [[budget deficit]], amongst continued protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-05/greek-protests-mount-as-parliament-passes-budget-cuts-correct-.html|title=Greek Protests Mount as Parliament Passes Budget Cuts (Update4)|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=5 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/07/world/europe/07greece.html|title=Greek Parliament Passes Austerity Measures|work=New York Times|date=5 May 2010|first=Dan|last=Bilersky}} Also on 5 May, the German parliament began debating the bailout package, as Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] urged rapid passage. Merkel remarked that "Quite simply, Europe's future is at stake." The plan requires Germany to provide the largest share, {{Nowrap|€22 billion}}, of the bailout funds. The plan must be approved by 15 [[Eurozone]] countries in total. Analysts said the protests could mark the beginning of protracted [[social unrest]]. If that occurs, the country could be pushed into deep recession. Economists have warned that it could be ten years before the Greek economy recovers, even if it does not worsen first. There has been advocacy for a [[political coalition]] from within the Greek political elite, and by the Greek journalist [[Alexis Papahelas]] who said that Papandreou should 'get rid of some of the novices he has in his government, make an overture to the opposition and go full-steam ahead.'{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_columns_100006_06/05/2010_116895|title=Which path will we take?|publisher=[[Kathimerini]]|first=Alexis|last=Papachelas}} One columnist at [[The Guardian]] suggested in an editorial that the protests speak of a deeper issue in Greek politics: she asks, 'What the advocates of this scenario [coalition government] do not seem to grasp is that the political class is out of touch with the population,' and 'How can we expect to see solutions and progress by the very same people who are inextricably, causally linked to the problem?'{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/may/06/national-unity-greece-crisis|title=Greek debt crisis: coalition won't solve anything|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=6 May 2010|first=Matina|last=Stevis }} However other sources{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/22936994/Beyond_Spontaneity|title=Beyond Spontaneity|website=www.academia.edu|access-date=11 April 2016}} suggest that the movement was a positive reaction triggering a series of innovative socio-political processes. ==Background of the 2011 protests== [[File:Greece public debt 1999-2010.svg|thumb|The first round of austerity in 2010 failed to stop Greece's rising debt, which is expected to go up by 10% in 2011.{{cite web|title=Προβλέψεις της Ευρ. Επιτροπής |url=http://www.tovima.gr/finance/article/?aid=400463 |publisher=To Vima |accessdate=3 July 2011}}]] {{further|2010 European sovereign debt crisis#Greek government funding crisis|Economy of Greece#2010 debt crisis}} The memorandum signed between Greece and the IMF became largely unpopular in Greece, with some polls showing that 62% believe it was a bad decision. This memorandum came into action 7 October 2011.{{cite web|title=Mνημόνιο ένα χρόνο μετά: Aποδοκιμασία, αγανάκτηση, απαξίωση, ανασφάλεια |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/169875/mnimonio-ena-hrono-meta-apodokimasia-aganaktisi-apaxiosi-anasfaleia/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=18 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}} Amid accusations that the government has not achieved its goals according to the IMF memorandum, some countries in the [[European Union]] have stated that they will not be lending Greece any more money if the IMF does not do so, including the Netherlands, Germany and Sweden.{{cite web|title=Σκληρή γραμμή έναντι της Αθήνας από τους Ολλανδούς |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170745/skliri-grammi-enadi-tis-athinas-apo-tous-ollandous-/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Ενέχυρο κρατική περιουσία θέλουν Γερμανία, Φινλανδία και Ολλανδία |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170713/enehuro-kratiki-periousia-theloun-germania-finlandia-kai-ollandia-/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=28 May 2011}} Some European officials went so far as to say that Greece should start selling its assets to other European nations to receive loans, and the [[Dutch people|Dutch]] Minister of Finance said that the Greek parliament would not like this proposal and characterised the opinion of the Greek parliament as "a sensibility" that no one can consider at this time. Meanwhile, unemployment exceeded 15%, while a large percentage of full-time workers only received the minimum wage of 592 Euros, or less.{{cite web|title=Την ελάχιστη αμοιβή παίρνει το 25% των εργαζομένων- Ακάλυπτοι από το νόμο οι άνεργοι |url=http://news.in.gr/economy/article/?aid=1231110553 |publisher=in.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011|date=27 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Στο 15,9% η ανεργία το Φεβρουάριο |url=http://www.imerisia.gr/article.asp?catid=12336&subid=2&pubid=111171174 |publisher=imerisia.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011|date=13 May 2011}} Rumours suggesting Greece's future exclusion from the [[Eurozone]] also added to frustration, but these were categorically rejected by the Greek government, the [[European Central Bank]], the [[Bank of Greece]] and IMF-director nominee, and French Finance Minister, [[Christine Lagarde]].{{cite web|title=Λαγκάρντ: Η αλληλεγγύη αντίστοιχη με τις ελληνικές προσπάθειες |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170752/papadimos-i-katastasi-tis-oikonomias-epideinothike-/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Προβόπουλος: Παντελώς γελοία τα περί εξόδου από το ευρώ |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/finance/article/170661/provopoulos-padelos-geloia-ta-peri-exodou-apo-to-euro-/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=27 May 2011}} On 29 June 2011, amid violent protests, the second austerity package was passed with 155 votes in favour in the 300-seat parliament. The next day, the Office of the [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] of the United Nations reported an independent UN expert's warning that the austerity measures could result in violations of the Greek people's human rights, such as "rights to food, water, adequate housing and work under fair and equitable conditions".{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=38901&Cr=austerity&Cr1= |title=Greek austerity measures could violate human rights, UN expert says |date=30 June 2011|publisher=United Nations |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Meanwhile, other international media have questioned the necessity of a second austerity package, when the first one brought in no results.{{cite news|title=Greece and austerity: Brussels v the people |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jun/29/greece-austerity-brussels-people?intcmp=239 |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=4 July 2011|date=29 June 2011}} When Greece signed the Memorandum with the European Union and the IMF in 2010, the matter of the constitutional legality of the memorandum came under criticism in Greece, both by the people and some of the country's most prominent university professors of law.{{cite web|title=Και "Αρμα" κατά του Μνημονίου |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.article&id=267498 |publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}}{{cite web|title=Ανάλυση στα γεγονότα |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=issue.el.home&date=15/04/2011&s=analysh-sta-gegonota |publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}} The Athens Association of Lawyers, as well as a number of labour unions, brought the question of the legality of the memorandum to the [[Council of State (Greece)|Council of State]] of the Greek government, but the Council judged the contract to be constitutional in late June 2011.{{cite web|title="Mάχη" για την συνταγματικότητα του μνημονίου |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=88822 |publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}}{{cite web|title=ΣτΕ: Συνταγματικό το Μνημόνιο |url=http://portal.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_kathbreak_1_21/06/2011_395425 |publisher=kathimerini.gr |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Apart from the economic crisis, there is also a developing political crisis in the country. The [[European Commission]] asked the major parties in Greece to come to an agreement in regards to the new set of austerity measures, but twice the major parties failed.{{cite web|title=Xωρίς συναίνεση στα φλέγοντα θέματα |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/170679/horis-sunainesi-sta-flegoda-themata/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=27 May 2011}} In a poll published on 29 May 2011, the two major parties (the ruling [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] and the main opposition [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]]) gathered slightly under 40% of the total number of votes, with the ruling party having 19%, while the opposition came first with 19.5%.{{cite web|title=Μόλις που ξεπερνάει το 40% ο δικομματισμός |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=279636 |publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}} In another poll published the same day, the ruling party came first with 20.7% while the opposition came second with 20.4%. According to the polls, neither of the two parties could form a government, even if they combined forces.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The lack of co-ordination within the government (with conflicting government officials stating opposing 'government positions') also fuelled the protests.{{cite web|title=Θα μας τρελάνουν! |url=http://www.protothema.gr/politics/article/?aid=124866 |publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}} When [[Maria Damanaki]], [[European Commissioner for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]], stated that "our withdrawal from the Eurozone is on the table, we have to speak frankly" on 25 May,{{cite web|title=Για κίνδυνο εξόδου από το ευρώ μιλάει και η Μ.Δαμανάκη |url=http://www.protothema.gr/politics/article/?aid=124262 |publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=25 May 2011}} Greek banks lost liquidity equal to 1.5 billion Euro from withdrawals in two days.{{cite web|title=Panic Capital Flight in Greece, Depositors Yank 1.5 Billion Euros in 2 Days; EU Wants Severe Bail-Out Conditions Including International Tax Collection |url=http://globaleconomicanalysis.blogspot.com/2011/05/panic-capital-flight-in-greece.html |publisher=Mish's Global Economic Trend Analysis |accessdate=3 July 2011|date=30 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=Σήκωσαν 1,5 δισ. ευρώ Πέμπτη και Παρασκευή από τις τράπεζες |url=http://www.protothema.gr/economy/article/?aid=124771 |publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011|date=28 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110701061627/http://www.protothema.gr/economy/article/?aid=124771| archivedate= 1 July 2011| deadurl= no}} Meanwhile, the Minister of Finance, [[Giorgos Papakonstantinou]], vehemently denied that exiting the Eurozone was being considered. On 1 June, the leader of the [[Popular Orthodox Rally]] party, [[Georgios Karatzaferis]], announced that his party is considering resigning from parliament, thus causing the dissolution of the [[Hellenic Parliament]] and triggering national elections.{{cite web|title=Γ. Καρατζαφέρης: Σκέφτομαι να αποσύρω το ΛΑΟΣ από τη Βουλή |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=10&artid=95412 |publisher=agelioforos.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011|date=1 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=Καρατζαφέρης: Θα πάρω τους βουλευτές μου και θα φύγω |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=280598 |publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011|date=1 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=Καρατζαφέρης: Εξετάζει την αποχώρηση του ΛΑΟΣ από τη Βουλή |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/171054/karatzaferis-exetazei-tin-apohorisi-tou-laos-apo-ti-vouli-/ |publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=1 June 2011|date=1 June 2011}} He also commented that "I see a Prime Minister that is unable to react, an opposition that is unwilling to play the game, and a [[Left (politics)|Left]] that is in its own little world". ==2011 protests== ===February 2011=== On 23 February 2011, there was a recurrence of violent protests and strikes, involving up to 100,000 people{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/201122316141729962.html |title=Clashes break out at Greek protests – Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=23 February 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629082808/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/201122316141729962.html| archivedate= 29 June 2011| deadurl= no}} as German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] called for a renewal of the loan programme to Greece{{cite news|last=Czuczka |first=Tony |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/merkel-says-eu-considering-extension-of-financial-aid-program-for-greece.html |title=Merkel Says EU Considering Extension of Financial Aid Program for Greece |publisher=Bloomberg |date=23 February 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629024609/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/merkel-says-eu-considering-extension-of-financial-aid-program-for-greece.html| archivedate= 29 June 2011| deadurl= no}} that had been conditioned on fiscal tightening. The measures adopted by Greece were considered harsh by the protesters. ==="Indignant Citizens Movement" (May–August)=== ====May==== [[File:Syntagma Square 'indignados'.png|thumb|Demonstrators in the plaza in front of the Greek parliament, 25 May.]] [[File:Real Democracy Now information kiosk.png|thumb|The [[Real Democracy Now! (Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] information kiosk at Syntagma Square, 31 May.]] On 25 May 2011, peaceful demonstrations started in Athens and other major cities, protesting the new austerity measures proposed by the government, in the same spirit as the [[2011 Spanish protests]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sigmalive.com/news/greece/386263 |title=Ελλάδα: πλήθος πολιτών διαδήλωσαν για τα μέτρα λιτότητας |publisher=Sigma Live |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=278646 |title=Δίχως κόμμα, συνδικάτο, μόνο οργή (Without a party or syndicate, just anger) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=eleftherotypia.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The demonstrations include most major Greek cities: [[Athens]], [[Thessaloniki]], [[Larissa]], [[Patras]], [[Volos]], [[Rethymno]], [[Tripoli (Greece)|Tripoli]] and [[Kalamata]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ert.gr/index.php/eidiseis/ellada/38-koinonia/6516-2011-05-26-18-55-52.html |title=Νέα συγκέντρωση στο Σύνταγμα (New demonstration at Syntagma) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=news.ert.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110611040619/http://www.ert.gr/index.php/eidiseis/ellada/38-koinonia/6516-2011-05-26-18-55-52.html| archivedate= 11 June 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite web|author=Ελλάδα |url=http://www.greek-radar.gr/iaganaktismeni-polites-sigkentrononte-sto-sintagma/ |title=Ελλάδα – Πάνω από 20.000 οι "αγανακτισμένοι'' πολίτες στο Σύνταγμα! |date=29 October 2010|accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170493/oi-aganaktismenoi-diadilonoun-stis-ellinikes-poleis-/ |title=Οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" διαδηλώνουν στις ελληνικές πόλεις (The 'indignants' protest in Greek cities) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The demonstration in Athens is coordinated by the Facebook page "Αγανακτισμένοι Στο Σύνταγμα" (Indignants at [[Syntagma Square|Syntagma]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/%CE%91%CE%B3%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BA%CF%84%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B5%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CE%A3%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%A3%CF%85%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%B3%CE%BC%CE%B1/210627972310743 |script-title=el:Αγανακτισμενοι Στο Συνταγμα |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Currently, it is reported that over 90,000 people have registered on the page,{{cite web|url=http://www.newsplus.gr/index.php?v=2&aid=34149 |title=newsplus | Χιλιάδες Έλληνες δηλώνουν ..."Πάμε Πλατεία"! – Ελλάδα, κοινωνία |publisher=Newsplus.gr |accessdate=30 June 2011}} and thousands (reportedly over 30,000) have gathered outside the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]] in Syntagma square.{{cite web|url=http://www.star.gr/ellada_kosmos/93174/ |title=Σε εξέλιξη η συγκέντρωση των "Αγανακτισμένων" στο Σύνταγμα |publisher=Star.Gr |date=7 October 2010|accessdate=30 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110717044100/http://www.star.gr/ellada_kosmos/93174/| archivedate= 17 July 2011| deadurl= no}}[http://roarmag.org/2011/05/greek-revolution-protests-live-stream-syntagma-square/ Livestream of the protests at Syntagma Square, Athens | Reflections on a Revolution ROAR] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528032108/http://roarmag.org/2011/05/greek-revolution-protests-live-stream-syntagma-square/ |date=28 May 2011 }} The demonstration in Greece's second-largest city, [[Thessaloniki]], is co-ordinated by the Facebook page "Αγανακτισμένοι στον Λευκό Πύργο" (Indignants at the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]]), and over 35,000 people have said they would 'attend' the protest.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=206334352736094&ref=ts |script-title=el:ΑΓΑΝΑΚΤΙΣΜΕΝΟΙ ΣΤΟΝ ΛΕΥΚΟ ΠΥΡΓΟ |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Some of the most popular slogans at protest on 25 May were: *Error 404, Democracy was not found.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/agencias/noticia.asp?noticia=841597|title=Sinde recibida en San Sebastián por los "indignados" al grito de "fuera"|date=6 June 2011|publisher=ABC Periódico Electrónico|language=Spanish|accessdate=12 June 2011}} *I vote, You vote, He votes, She votes, We vote, You vote, They steal. *Greece your turn has come, you have to stop burying your children.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74247/ |script-title=el:Αγανάκτησαν οι πολίτες |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=makthes.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} *Oust! (Greek interjection of a negative nature, meaning "leave") *The maid resisted. What do we do? (Reference to [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn sexual assault case|an alleged sex scandal]] involving former IMF director [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]]) This series of demonstrations differed from almost all other demonstrations in Greece's [[metapolitefsi]] era (1975–present) in that it was a protest organised without political or trade union affiliations. Demonstrators who expressed political party affiliation during the demonstrations were condemned by the majority of the demonstrators, as the organizers claimed that there was no room for political affiliation or violence in the demonstrations. The focus of the protesters was against the government and the current driving forces of [[Politics of Greece|Greek politics]], and the [[International Monetary Fund]]. As a response to the Spanish slogan "Be quiet, the Greeks are sleeping" (which was allegedly heard at the [[2011 Spanish protests]]),{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=issue.el.home&date=25/05/2011&id=278406 |title=Το σύνθημα που άκουσαν μόνο τα ελληνικά ΜΜΕ (The slogan that only Greek media heard) |language=Greek |date=25 May 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} a big banner was raised in front of the Spanish embassy in Athens reading "¡Estamos despiertos! ¿Que hora es? ¡Ya es hora de que se vayan!" (We've woken up! What time is it? It's time they left!).{{cite web |url=http://www.e-typos.com/content.aspx?cid=23219&catid=7 |title=Eλλάδα: Υπό βροχή, αλλά πιστοί στο ραντεβού στο Σύνταγμα, οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" πολίτες (Greece: under the rain the outraged citizens are at Syntagma again") |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=e-typos.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} There was also a strong sense of disapproval for the [[Prime Minister of Greece]], [[George Papandreou]], and the vice-president of the government, [[Theodoros Pangalos (politician)|Theodoros Pangalos]].{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=278917 |script-title=el:Η αγανάκτηση νίκησε την καταιγίδα |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} The demonstrations continued nationwide for a second day on 26 May.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74247/ |title=Αγανάκτησαν οι πολίτες (The citizens are outraged) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=makthes.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170575/i-diamarturia-sto-sudagma-zodana-sto-skaigr/ |title=Οι διαμαρτυρίες σε Σύνταγμα και Πάτρα ζωντανά στο SKAI.gr (The demonstrations at Syntagma and Patras live on SKAI.gr) |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} Despite heavy rainfall in central Athens, reportedly over 14,000 people gathered in front of the Greek parliament for a second day in a row.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/TV/?MMID=214612 |script-title=el:Συνεχίζονται οι διαμαρτυρίες |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The media reported that half of the people gathered at Syntagma Square in Athens were youth, whereas the other half were over 40, including families and children. In line with the Spanish quote of "Be quiet, the Greeks are sleeping" which triggered the Greek protests, two new banners appeared, one in French (Silence! Les Français dorment! Ils revent de '68, ''Silence! The French are sleeping! They are dreaming of (May) '68'') and one in Italian (Zitti che svegliamo gli Italiani... ''Be quiet, you will wake up the Italians...''). An information center and a "book of ideas" have also been set up at Syntagma Square.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/tv/?mmid=214618 |script-title=el:Χιλιάδες πολίτες και εχθές στο Σύνταγμα |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Additionally, a number of people were banging pots and pans. In [[Thessaloniki]], Greece's second city and second-largest center of demonstrations, the protesters hung a huge For Sale sign from the city's main landmark, the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]], as a protest against the government's massive denationalisation schedule, which they perceived as "selling away our country's assets".{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74304/ |script-title=el:Ξανά στον Λευκό Πύργο οι αγανακτισμένοι |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011|publisher=makthes.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=94610 |script-title=el:Θεσσαλονίκη: Σήμερα στις 18:00 για τρίτη ημέρα στον Λευκό Πύργο οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011|publisher=agelioforos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Although the demonstrations in Thessaloniki were visibly smaller on 26 May, with around 2,500 people participating, competing with a major football game between the city's two major teams and the shops and markets open until late that evening. Some people set up encampments. In Thessaloniki's protests there was much more of a sense of direct democracy, as citizens were free to take the floor and speak, voice their concerns and opinions, and contribute ideas about what should be done next, receiving the full attention of the other demonstrators.{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=94405 |script-title=el:Και σήμερα άρχισαν να συγκεντρώνονται στον Λευκό Πύργο οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=agelioforos.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} [[File:Vote of the People's Assembly of Syntagma Square.svg|thumb|The first vote of the people's assembly of Syntagma Square.{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%88%CE%AE%CF%86%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B1-%CE%BB%CE%B1%CF%8A%CE%BA%CE%AE%CF%82-%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%AD%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CF%83%CE%B7%CF%82-%CF%80%CE%BB%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82-%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B3%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82-0 |script-title=el:Ψήφισμα λαϊκής συνέλευσης Πλατείας Συντάγματος |language=Greek |publisher=real-democracy.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}}]] Demonstrations continued for a third consecutive day on 27 May.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=124746 |script-title=el:Στο Σύνταγμα για τρίτη μέρα οι Αγανακτισμένοι |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170612/neo-radevou-apo-tous-aganaktismenous/ |script-title=el:Νέο ραντεβού από τους "Αγανακτισμένους" |language=Greek |date=27 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=27 May 2011}} Thousands of people gathered in front of the Greek parliament, again in heavy downpour, joined by the "I'm Not Paying" movement. As a means of protesting, people wearing white masks formed a human shield around the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, in Syntagma Square. The demonstrations continued peacefully, and when one protester shouted a slogan against the police, he was heavily condemned by other demonstrators. On 27 May, the proceedings of the first [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] on Syntagma Square were published by the [[Real Democracy Now! (Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] movement. Among them:{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/node/47 |title=Proceedings of the First Assembly |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=real-democracy.gr |accessdate=26 May 2011}} *Any corrupt politician should either be sent home or to jail. *When we, the people, start discussions without fear, fear grips them, inside the parliament building. *This is not just the politician's fault. It's all our faults, with our selfish attitudes. *Demonstrations should take place every evening at 6 pm and an [[Popular assembly|assembly]] at 9 pm. *Their democracy guarantees neither Justice nor Equality. *The taxation system is not the same for the rich and the poor. Equal rights for everyone. On 28 May, demonstrations continued with at least 7,000 people gathered in front of the Greek parliament.{{cite web |url=http://www.star.gr/ellada_kosmos/93565 |script-title=el:"Αγανακτισμένοι": "είστε προδότες" |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011|publisher=star.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} A number of new flags appeared, including those of Tunisia, Argentina, Armenia and Hungary. At least 20 people set up tents in the square. Major demonstrations also took place in Thessaloniki, Patras and Heraklion.{{cite web |url=http://www.star.gr/politics/93597/ |script-title=el:"Επιμένουν για τέταρτη μέρα οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011|publisher=star.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} In Thessaloniki a cycling race was organised as part of the demonstration.{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=279623 |script-title=el:Οι πλατείες είναι γεμάτες για 4η μέρα |language=Greek |date=28 May 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=28 May 2011}} All across the country the movement was becoming more organised, media reported, with teams of doctors, translators, and food supplies set up by the protesters, especially at Syntagma Square, which had turned into the main protest center for the country. [[File:2011 Greece Uprising.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament, 29 May.]] 29 May was set as a day of peaceful pan-European demonstrations.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=225690444124218 |title=EUROPEAN REVOLUTION 29 MAY—ALL CITIES OF EUROPE |language=Greek |date=26 May 2011|publisher=facebook.com |accessdate=26 May 2011}} It was estimated that the demonstration in Athens alone attracted more than 100,000 demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament,{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170780/pano-apo-100000-oi-aganaktismenoi-sto-sudagma-/ |script-title=el:Στους 100.000 οι "Αγανακτισμένοι στο Σύνταγμα" |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125014 |title=100.000 πολίτες βουλιάζουν το Σύνταγμα! |language=Greek |date=29 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110531162506/http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125014| archivedate= 31 May 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/BUSINESS/05/30/greece.bailout.ft/index.html |title=Greece set for severe bail-out conditions |date=29 May 2011 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603040956/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/BUSINESS/05/30/greece.bailout.ft/index.html |archivedate=3 June 2011 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/29/spanish-inspired-protest-grips-athens/ |title=Spanish-inspired protest grips Athens |date=29 May 2011|publisher=euronews.eu |accessdate=29 May 2011}} while others put the estimates around 80,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170810/neo-radevou-ton-aganaktismenon-to-apogeuma-tis-deuteras/ |script-title=el:Πιστοί στο έκτο ραντεβού τους οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" |language=Greek |date=30 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} Demonstrations included people of all ages and financial backgrounds. The oldest person at the demonstration was a 102-year-old grandmother looking after her granddaughter, who also spoke at the [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] in support of the demonstrations.{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63105080 |title=Η μεγαλύτερη βραδιά της αγανάκτησης |date=29 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=29 May 2011}} An estimated 10,000 people gathered in front of the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki]] in Greece's second city, and demonstrations were also held in many other Greek cities.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/reportage/74531/ |title=Σας περιμένουμε στον Πύργο το Λευκό... |date=30 May 2011|publisher=makthes.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}} Some of the most popular slogans that were heard on 29 May were "the worst form of violence is poverty" and "a magical night, like in Argentina, lets see who gets in the helicopter first!", a reference to [[President of Argentina|Argentine President]] [[Fernando de la Rúa]]'s resignation and escape from the presidential mansion using a helicopter in 2001. Some of the demands that the [[Real Democracy Now! (Greece)|Real Democracy Now!]] movement has formulated during the [[Popular assembly|assemblies]] at syntagma Square include:{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%87%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AE%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B6%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%AE%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82 |title=Στόχοι του κινήματος/Συζητήσεις |date=27 May 2011|publisher=real-democracy.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}} *Adoption of a new constitution, written by the people and not the members of parliament *Refusal to pay debt which members of the movement consider to be [[odious debt|odious]] *Cancellation of the memorandum signed between Greece and the [[International Monetary Fund]] *Harder taxation on the rich. [[File:Vote of the People's Assembly of the White Tower Square.svg|thumb|A similar vote was issued by the people's assembly in Thessaloniki.{{cite web |url=http://aganaktismenoi-thess.blogspot.com/2011/05/3005.html |script-title=el:ΨΗΦΙΣΜΑ ΤΗΣ ΣΥΝΕΛΕΥΣΗΣ ΤΟΥ ΛΕΥΚΟΥ ΠΥΡΓΟΥ 30/05 |language=Greek |date=30 May 2011|publisher=aganaktismenoi-thess.blogspot.com |accessdate=31 May 2011}}]] 30 May saw continued demonstrations in Athens and other cities around Greece, although visibly smaller than the demonstrations of 29 May.{{cite web |url=http://makthes.gr/news/politics/74556/ |title=Για 6η μέρα οι "αγανακτισμένοι" στον Λευκό Πύργο |date=30 May 2011|publisher=makthes.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=280019 |title=Ψηλαφώντας την Αμεση Δημοκρατία |date=31 May 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} More than 4,000 people demonstrated in front of the Greek parliament on 30 May,{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63105303 |title=Στην πλατεία πάλι οι "Αγανακτισμένοι" |date=30 May 2011|publisher=ethnos.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} with some sources claiming that over 10,000 people were present.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125447 |title=Νέο ραντεβού των Αγανακτισμένων στο Σύνταγμα |date=31 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} The demonstrators also set up a set of [[gallow]]s in front of the parliament, demanding that those responsible for the crisis be sent to justice. Over 30 tents were set up in front of the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki]] in Greece's second-largest city, where a direct democracy style [[Popular assembly|people's assembly]] took place every evening. 31 May marked seven days since the start of the protests, and the [[University of Athens]] hosted an anti-government protest with the aid of famous Greek composer and anti-dictatorship fighter [[Mikis Theodorakis]], while the dean of the University was also a key speaker at the event. Once the protest at the university was over, the 10,000 protesters joined forces with the demonstrators already in front of the parliament,{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125447 |title=50.000 πολίτες στο κέντρο της Αθήνας |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} totalling between 25,000 and 50,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/170979/evdomi-imera-aganaktisis/ |script-title=el:Σε "κατάσταση πολιορκίας" το Κοινοβούλιο |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} The demonstrators surrounded the Greek parliament, making it impossible for MPs and workers inside the building to exit. Eight MPs escaped through the adjacent National Gardens. Later, riot police created a passage to enable MPs to exit the parliament, to the loud condemnation of 1,000 protesters gathered at the side entrance.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125512 |script-title=el:Αστακός η είσοδος της Βουλής |language=Greek |date=31 May 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=31 May 2011}} ====June==== Demonstrations continued on 1 June. At [[Corfu]], protesters surrounded a restaurant where Greek and foreign members of parliament were having a dinner, shouting slogans against them while a few were throwing rocks and other objects at the politicians.{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=125669 |script-title=el:Έφυγαν με σκάφος για να γλιτώσουν από τους Αγανακτισμένους |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011|publisher=protothema.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171153/bloko-aganaktismenon-se-vouleutes-stin-kerkura/ |script-title=el:"Μπλόκο" αγανακτισμένων σε βουλευτές στην Κέρκυρα |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=280706 |script-title=el:Βουλευτές φυγαδεύθηκαν με... καΐκι στην Κέρκυρα |language=Greek |date=2 June 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}} Finally, the officials were forced to escape using a boat, as the restaurant was near the harbour. In Athens, more than 15,000 people gathered in front of the parliament to protest for an eighth day in a row. This time they were also joined by the ''Society for the Protection of Citizens by the Arbitration of Banks'', and also a group of motorcyclists who also showed their support for the protests. Earlier that evening the riot police had closed up the streets leading up to the embassy of Egypt. To avoid being blockaded inside the parliament like on 31 May, the members of parliament left early on 1 June. Among thousands of protesters in Syntagma square, 32 Greek scientists addressed a letter to the members of parliament calling them to announce the whole truth of the situation{{cite web |url=http://www.zougla.gr/page.ashx?pid=2&aid=322783&cid=6 |script-title=el:Τολμήστε! |language=Greek |date=1 June 2011|publisher=zougla.gr |accessdate=2 June 2011}} [[File:Greek indignants cleaning streets, day 22.png|thumb|Indignants cleaning the streets around Syntagma Square on their 22nd day of protest on 15 June.]] 5 June was set as a second day of pan-European demonstrations and marked the 12th continuous day of demonstrations. It is estimated that well over 200,000 gathered at Athens' [[Syntagma Square]] that evening to protest against the government.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171424/aganaktismenoi-protofanis-summetohi-se-athina-kai-alles-poleis-/ |script-title=el:"Αγανακτισμένοι": Πρωτοφανής συμμετοχή σε Αθήνα και άλλες πόλεις |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110717160132/http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171424/aganaktismenoi-protofanis-summetohi-se-athina-kai-alles-poleis-/| archivedate= 17 July 2011| deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=281844 |script-title=el:Εκκωφαντική λαοθάλασσα στο Σύνταγμα |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011|publisher=enet.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}} Some sources put the number of people in front of the parliament to over 300,000{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=126165 |title=300.000 πολίτες στο κέντρο της Αθήνας! |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}} while the organizers claim that over 500,000 people took part in the demonstration, making it the largest demonstration in Athens since the 1980s.{{cite web|title=Videos from the Indignant Citizens Movement in Athens 2011|url=http://www.athenswalk.net/_/Blog/Entries/2013/8/24_Indignant-Citizens-Movement.html}} At the [[popular assembly|people's assembly]] a direct connection with [[Madrid]]'s [[Puerta del Sol]] was made via [[Skype]]. Some tension occurred on 5 June, as protesters were prevented from heading towards [[Syntagma Square]] by riot police, which had put together large metallic barriers to close off streets. Police also brought a [[water cannon]] to the protests. Demonstrations also took place in [[Thessaloniki]], [[Patras]] and [[Heraklion]], as well as many other Greek cities. Some of the most popular slogans of that day included: *Bread-Education-Freedom – the dictatorship didn't fall in '73! *We do not owe, we will not sell away, we will not pay. *Minister of culture, minister of censorship [[File:June 29 Athens street fire.png|thumb|A bin on fire during riots of 29 June in a street near parliament.]] [[Image:20110629 Old man hit by Riot Police in demonstrations in Athens Greece.jpg|thumb|Clash between riot police and a citizen – 29 June 2011.]] Demonstrations continued throughout June, both at [[Syntagma Square]] and other squares in cities across the country. On 28 June 2011, Greek unions, including those whose members dominate the country's health, transportation, education, and government jobs began a 48-hour strike, in protest of the deteriorating economic situation and suggestions on the part of the government of new austerity measures.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/greek-unions-launch-48-hour-strike-against-austerity-measures-1.370020 |title=Greek unions launch 48-hour strike against austerity measures |date=28 June 2011|work=Haaretz |location=Israel |accessdate=29 June 2011}} The walkout led to the freezing of a number of public services. Journalists and a number of artists also stopped working in solidarity with the protest. That day demonstrations turned violent as protestors clashed with police in front of the Greek parliament and other areas of central [[Athens]]. Violence continued during the night and on 29 June, the day when a new package of deeply unpopular austerity measures was passed.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13953077 |title=Greece crisis: Greece crisis: MPs vote on austerity package |accessdate=29 June 2011|work=BBC News |date=29 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629112143/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13953077| archivedate= 29 June 2011| deadurl= no}} The police attempted to evacuate Syntagma Square of protesters, as well as other key protest points in Athens, by driving through the crowds on motorbikes and throwing stun grenades while making extensive use of tear gas.{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/173545/se-pedio-mahis-ehei-metatrapei-to-sudagma/ |script-title=el:Ηρεμία επικρατεί αυτή την ώρα στην πλατεία Συντάγματος |language=Greek |date=29 June 2011|publisher=skai.gr |accessdate=29 June 2011}} Media mentioned that the police used unnecessary violence against protesters. Officials from the [[Athens Metro]] also said that the police had fired [[tear gas]] inside the Syntagma Square metro station. Police also stormed [[Monastiraki]], as well as the streets around the [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]], randomly hitting people eating at taverns and making extensive use of chemicals and stun grenades.{{cite web | author= Dalakoglou Dimitris |title= The Irregularities of Violence in Athens | url= http://www.culanth.org/fieldsights/251-the-irregularities-of-violence-in-athens|year= 2011 |publisher=Cultural Anthropology |accessdate=1 July 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://tvxs.gr/news/%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%AC%CE%B4%CE%B1/%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%BA%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82-%CF%83%CE%B5-%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%BF-%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%BA%CE%AD%CE%BD%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF-%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B5%CE%BE%CE%AD%CE%BB%CE%B5%CE%B3%CE%BA%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%B7-%CE%B4%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%B1%CF%83%CF%84%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82 |script-title=el:Συγκρούσεις σε όλο το κέντρο-Ανεξέλεγκτη η δράση της αστυνομίας |language=Greek |date=29 June 2011|publisher=tvxs.gr |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Doctors at the infirmary set up at Othonos Square said the police had attacked them using stones and pieces of marble. Earlier, two members of the Teacher's Association were attacked by police and were injured, one of them on the head. Police also tried to deny access to the square to an ambulance attempting to transport heavily injured civilians to a hospital. A total of about 270 people were injured on 28 June alone, and over 500 visited the Syntagma Square metro station infirmary on 29 June.
