[[File:Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival Theater Tent.jpg|alt=HVSF theater tent|thumb|The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival theater tent at Boscobel House and Gardens]]
The '''Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival''' ('''HVSF''') is a non-profit professional theater company based at [[Boscobel (mansion)|Boscobel]] in [[Garrison, New York]]. The festival runs a roughly twelve-week repertory season each year, operating under a large open-air theater tent. Its productions attract a total audience of about 50,000 from the Hudson Valley, New York City, and 40 US states.
HVSF also performs [[William Shakespeare]]'s works and live theater throughout the tri-state area by touring. The company has limited runs of its most popular programs through its "HVSF On The Road" series and brings student-oriented productions and education programs to about 50,000 elementary, middle, and high school students and teachers each year. HVSF’s arts education programs also include training for early-career theater artists by way of its Conservatory Company, professional development for educators, and free audience engagement offerings before and after performances throughout the summer.
==History== HVSF was founded by Melissa Stern and Terry O’Brien in September 1987 with an outdoor production of ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]'' at [[Manitoga]], home of industrial designer [[Russel Wright]], in Garrison, New York. The following year, Boscobel House and Gardens agreed to host HVSF’s mainstage season on the estate’s expansive grounds, and that summer’s production of Shakespeare’s ''[[As You Like It]]'' was performed under a tent overlooking the Hudson River.
In 1994, the festival added a second show to its season and began hands-on, performance-driven education programs within area schools. In 2004, HVSF began to tour productions to middle and high schools. In 2006, HVSF acquired a custom-designed, open-air theater tent with seating for 540.
The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival was the subject of a one-hour documentary and two hour film of a performance of ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' which premiered on the [[PBS]] affiliate [[WNET]] (Channel 13 in New York City) on September 18, 2008. The program also aired on WLIW (Channel 21 on Long Island).<ref>[http://video.thirteen.org/episode/show/1672]''[[PBS]]''</ref><ref>[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/120398.html]''[[Playbill]]''</ref>
More than 500,000 patrons have been served since HVSF's first season in 1987. Terry O’Brien led the theater for 27 years, directing more than 30 productions, and stepped down as Artistic Director in December 2013. After a search for his successor, HVSF’s Board of Directors appointed Davis McCallum as Artistic Director in May 2014.
In 2016, the festival produced a community-driven production of Thornton Wilder's ''[[Our Town]]'' with a cast of about 40 citizen actors from the Hudson Valley region, directed by John Christian Plummer.
In 2017, the festival mounted its first new plays: ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' by Kate Hamill (adapted from the novel by [[Jane Austen]]), and [[Lauren Gunderson]]'s ''The Book of Will''.
==Location== With its plays performed in an open-air theater tent on the grounds of the Boscobel, the festival is known for its backdrop.<ref name="obrien">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/07/movies/nature-s-a-stage-and-often-a-player.html?smid=pl-share|title=Nature's a Stage and Often a Player|last=Marks|first=Peter|date=7 July 2000|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name=newsday>{{Cite news|title=Hudson Valley Shakespeare fest returns to Boscobel|last=Serico|first=Chris|date=11 June 2012|publisher=Newsday|url=http://newyork.newsday.com/entertainment/things-to-do/hudson-valley-shakespeare-fest-returns-to-boscobel-1.3770457}}</ref> The stage, a rough patch of dirt that is on the same level as the first few rows of the audience, recedes into lawns with a view<ref name=obrien/> of the [[Hudson River]] and [[West Point, New York|West Point]] in the distance.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=THE UNCERTAIN ART: Is There a Doctor in the House?|last=Nuland|first=Sherwin B.|journal=The American Scholar|volume=69|issue=4|date=Autumn 2000|jstor=41213080}}</ref> The company uses the vast open space behind the stage as scenery for the plays.<ref name=newsday/> According to [[Ben Brantley]] of ''The New York Times'', "nature and Shakespeare are the stars" in this festival.<ref name=tempest>{{Cite news|title=Prospero May Manipulate Nature, but Here, Nature Sets the Stage|last=Brantley|first=Ben|publisher=The New York Times|date=3 August 2005|url=http://theater2.nytimes.com/2005/08/03/theater/reviews/03temp.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0}}</ref>
==Recognition== The festival was named among The New York Times' "50 Essential Summer Festivals" in 2016, was [[Hudson Valley (magazine)|Hudson Valley Magazine]]'s 2016 Editors’ Pick for Best Summer Theater, and was nominated for a Drama League Award for its 2015 production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream''.
It produces classic and new works with an economy of style, focusing on script, actors and audience with the Hudson River and [[Hudson Highlands]] as its set and setting.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Much Ado about Nothing by William Shakespeare|last=Gulley|first=Ervene|journal=Theatre Journal|volume=42|issue=2|date=May 1991|jstor=3208227}}</ref> [[The Wall Street Journal]] hails it as, "The most purely enjoyable summer Shakespeare festival in America," while The New York Times comments, "If anyone wonders about the future of live theater or asks where the audience is, the answer is 'Under that tent."<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/07/06/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/06theatwe.html]''[[New York Times]]''</ref>
It is listed as a "Major Festival" in the book ''Shakespeare Festivals Around the World'' by Marcus D. Gregio (Editor), 2004.
==Education programs== In addition to its summer productions, the festival sponsors year-round education programs to about 50,000 students and teachers annually. These programs include in-school residencies and theater arts workshops for students, resource workshops for educators, a fall touring production for students in grades K-5, a spring touring production for students in grades 6-12, its annual Shakespeare Summer Camp for ages 8–16, and the Teachers' Shakespeare Institute. HVSF's Conservatory Company, a performance based training program for 6 - 8 early career actors, offers on- and off-stage opportunities to work alongside the festival's acting company.
==Plays performed== *1987: A Midsummer Night's Dream *1988: As You Like It *1989: Twelfth Night *1990: Much Ado About Nothing *1991: Romeo and Juliet *1992: The Taming of the Shrew *1993: The Merry Wives of Windsor *1994: Macbeth, The Comedy of Errors *1995: The Tempest, The Two Gentlemen of Verona *1996: A Midsummer Night's Dream, Love’s Labour's Lost *1997: Tartuffe, As You Like It *1998: A Winter’s Tale, Much Ado About Nothing *1999: Titus Andronicus, Twelfth Night *2000: Measure for Measure, Taming of the Shrew *2001: Merchant of Venice, Romeo and Juliet *2002: Henry V, The Comedy of Errors *2003: All’s Well That Ends Well, Antony and Cleopatra *2004: Macbeth, The Merry Wives of Windsor *2005: The Tempest, The Two Gentlemen of Verona *2006: A Midsummer Night's Dream, The Rivals *2007: Richard III, As You Like It *2008: Cymbeline, Twelfth Night, Shakespeare Abridged *2009: Pericles, Much Ado About Nothing, Shakespeare Abridged *2010: Troilus and Cressida, The Taming of the Shrew, Bomb-itty of Errors *2011: Hamlet, The Comedy of Errors, Around the World in 80 Days *2012: Love’s Labour’s Lost, Romeo and Juliet, The 39 Steps *2013: King Lear, All’s Well That Ends Well, The Three Musketeers *2014: Othello, Two Gentleman of Verona, The Liar *2015: The Winter's Tale, A Midsummer Night's Dream, The Arabian Nights, An Iliad *2016: As You Like It, Macbeth, Measure for Measure, Our Town, So Please You (devised clown show) *2017: Twelfth Night, [[Kate Hamill]]'s ''Pride and Prejudice'', The Book of Will, Love's Labour's Lost, The General from America

[[documentary film]] directed by [[Leslee Udwin]] and is part of the [[BBC]]'s ongoing [[Storyville (TV series)|Storyville]] series.<ref name=SoulFilmMaker>{{cite news|title=Interview with Delhi gang rapist left 'stain on my soul', says British film maker|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/11446337/Interview-with-Delhi-gang-rapist-left-stain-on-my-soul-says-British-film-maker.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=3 March 2015}}</ref> The film is based on the [[2012 Delhi gang rape]] and murder of 23-year-old Jyoti Singh who was a [[physiotherapy]] student.<ref name=YoutubeBlock /><ref name=IndiaBansTV>{{cite news|title=India bans TV stations from showing interview with man who raped student|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/03/india-outraged-interview-man-convicted-gang-rape-student|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=4 March 2014}}</ref>
The film was scheduled to be aired on TV channels round the world on March 8, 2015 to coincide with [[International Women's Day]]. However, when excerpts of the film, which included an interview with Mukesh Singh, one of the four men convicted of the rape and murder, were broadcast, a court stay order prohibiting the broadcast was obtained by the Indian police.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dec 16 documentary: Media trials tend to influence judges, says HC|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/dec-16-documentary-media-trials-tend-to-influence-judges-says-hc/article1-1325487.aspx|accessdate=27 March 2015|quote=Delhi Police approached a lower court last week to prevent the broadcast on International Women’s Day.}}</ref> The BBC complied with the request and did not air the film in India. Yet it aired outside of India on 4 March, was uploaded on [[YouTube]], and soon went [[viral video|viral]] via shares on social media. On 5 March, the Indian government directed YouTube to block the video in India.<ref name=YoutubeBlock>{{cite news|title=India asks YouTube to block banned rape film|url=https://news.yahoo.com/delhi-rape-victims-father-urges-viewing-documentary-080939613.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[Yahoo News]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=YoutubeBlocks>{{cite news|title=YouTube blocks BBC's Nirbhaya documentary video|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/videos/532286/youtube-blocks-access-to-bbc-documentary-nirbhaya-in-india.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[India Today]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref>
== Background == {{Main|2012 Delhi gang rape}} [[File:Delhi protests-Another lamp-post revolutionary.jpg|thumbnail|200px|Students protesting at [[Raisina Hill]], [[Rajpath]], December 2012]] The documentary is based on the [[2012 Delhi gang rape|Delhi gang rape]], an incident that occurred on 16 December 2012 in [[South Delhi]].<ref name=Chaotic>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2258306/Delhi-gang-rape-Five-men-charged-Jyoti-Singh-Pandey-murder-appear-court.html | title=Judge bars Delhi gang rape defendants from chaotic courtroom after 150 people cram into space meant for 30 | work=[[Daily Mail]] | date=7 January 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Hills | first=Suzannah}}</ref> The victim, Jyoti Singh, watched the film ''[[Life of Pi (film)|Life of Pi]]'' with a male friend, Awindra Pratap Pandey,<ref name=tragedy>{{cite news | url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/exploring-the-lives-of-the-rape-victim-and-suspects-in-india-a-879187.html|title= Rape Tragedy in India: Dreams of 'the Fearless One'|work=Der Spiegel|date=25 January 2013 |first1=Matthias | last1=Schulz | first2=Wieland | last2=Wagner}}</ref> after which they boarded a privately run bus to return home.<ref name=Rahman>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/03/india-outraged-interview-man-convicted-gang-rape-student|title=India bans TV stations from showing interview with man who raped student |work=The Guardian|date=2015-03-04|first=Maseeh | last=Rahman}}</ref> She was [[assault]]ed and [[gang rape]]d on the bus; her friend was also physically assaulted during the incident. Both of them were subsequently thrown from the bus. She received [[Emergency medicine|emergency treatment]] including several [[surgery|surgeries]] in India and [[Singapore]] but died on 29 December 2012 due to the serious nature of the [[injury|injuries]] she sustained in the assault.<ref name=VicDies>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-20860569 | title=Delhi gang-rape victim dies in hospital in Singapore | work=[[BBC News]] | date=29 December 2012 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>
The incident received widespread media coverage. It was condemned and triggered widespread public protest and criticism of the [[Government of India|Indian government]] for not providing enough protection to women. International media covered the incident only after persistent public protests.<ref name=magnifies>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/30/world/asia/weak-response-of-india-government-in-rape-case-stokes-rage.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | title=Leaders’ Response Magnifies Outrage in India Rape Case | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=29 December 2012 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Yardley | first=Jim}}</ref>
Six men were arrested, including a 17-year-old juvenile, and accused as perpetrators of the assaults. One detainee was found dead in his prison cell, as a result of a possible suicide, although his relatives alleged that he had been murdered.<ref name=hanging>{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Suicide-or-murder-Nirbhaya-main-accused-found-hanging-in-Tihar/articleshow/18916760.cms?referral=PM | title=Suicide or murder? Nirbhaya main accused found hanging in Tihar | work=[[The Times of India]] | date=12 March 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Basu | first=Indrani}}</ref> The four accused men were found guilty and [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]],<ref name=Doubt>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/14/world/asia/4-sentenced-to-death-in-rape-case-that-riveted-india.html?emc=edit_na_20130913 | title=Many Doubt Death Sentences Will Stem India Sexual Attacks | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=13 September 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Barry | first=Ellen}}</ref> whilst the juvenile was given 3 years imprisonment, under the [[The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000|Juvenile Justice Act]].<ref name=juvenile>{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Nirbhaya-gang-rape-case-Juvenile-found-guilty-of-rape-and-murder/articleshow/22183253.cms | title=Nirbhaya gang-rape case: Juvenile found guilty of rape and murder | work=[[The Times of India]] | date=31 August 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>
== History ==
The film is part of the [[BBC]]'s ongoing [[Storyville (TV series)|Storyville]] series.<ref name=SoulFilmMaker/> It was planned to be broadcast on [[International Women's Day]], 8 March 2015,<ref name=clearance>{{cite news | url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/indias-daughter-required-clearances-were-taken-744072 | title=India's Daughter: Required Clearances Were Taken by Documentary Maker | work=[[NDTV]] | date=4 March 2015 | accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> in India on [[NDTV 24x7]] and in [[UK]] on [[BBC Four]].<!-- , whilst being simultaneously broadcast in [[Denmark]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]], [[Norway]] and [[Canada]]. --><ref name=Onsunday>{{cite news | url=http://www.media247.co.uk/bizasia/ndtv-24x7-to-air-nirbhaya-doc-on-sunday-2015 | title=NDTV 24×7 & BBC to air ‘Nirbhaya’ film on Sunday | work=[[NDTV 24x7]] | date=3 March 2015 | accessdate=4 March 2015 | last=Baddhan | first=Raj | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307223859/http://www.media247.co.uk/bizasia/ndtv-24x7-to-air-nirbhaya-doc-on-sunday-2015 | archivedate=7 March 2015 | df= }}</ref><!-- {{what|was it broadcast?}} --> On 1 March 2015, it was revealed that the film-makers had interviewed one of the rapists while he was being held in the [[Tihar jail]].<ref name=PrisonInterview>{{cite news|title=Delhi bus rapist blames his victim in prison interview|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/11443462/Delhi-bus-rapist-blames-his-victim-in-prison-interview.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=1 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=ThisStory>{{cite news|title=This story must be told, says filmmaker who interviewed Dec 16 rapist|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/filmmaker-accused-of-giving-platform-to-rapist-after-interview-with-december-16-convict/article1-1322618.aspx|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=3 March 2015}}</ref> Soon, the news was picked up by Indian [[news media|media outlets]].<ref name=ThisStory /><ref name=DuringRape>{{cite news|title=During rape the girl shouldn't fight back, says December 16 convict|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/delhi-december-16-gang-rape-mukesh-singh-bbc-interview/1/421930.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[India Today]]|date=6 March 2015}}</ref> The Indian government blocked its broadcast in India by obtaining a court order on 4 March 2015. The BBC said it would comply with the order and did not broadcast the film in India.<ref name="aired" /> In the UK however, the BBC moved the transmission forward to 4 March and it was shown on that date.<ref name=BBCForward>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/mar/04/indias-daughter-bbc-delhi-rape-documentary-uk-india-ban | title=India’s Daughter: BBC brings forward airing of Delhi rape documentary | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=4 March 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> The film was also uploaded on [[YouTube]] and soon went [[viral video|viral]] with various shares on social media. On 5 March, the Indian government directed YouTube to block the video in India.<ref name=YoutubeBlock>{{cite news|title=India asks YouTube to block banned rape film|url=https://news.yahoo.com/delhi-rape-victims-father-urges-viewing-documentary-080939613.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[Yahoo News]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> YouTube complied with the orders.<ref name=YoutubeBlocks>{{cite news|title=YouTube blocks BBC's Nirbhaya documentary video|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/videos/532286/youtube-blocks-access-to-bbc-documentary-nirbhaya-in-india.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[India Today]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> The film has generated a great deal of controversy in both India and worldwide.
Udwin has said it was the protests in response to the rape that drew her to make this film. "I was absolutely awestruck by the ordinary men and women of India who poured out onto the streets in response to this horrific gang rape and who demanded change for women's rights. And I thought the least I could do was amplify their voices."<ref>https://www.npr.org/2015/11/01/453739552/indias-daughter-opens-in-u-s-after-being-banned-in-india</ref>
== Interview == One of the convicted rapists serving life imprisonment, Mukesh Singh, was interviewed for the documentary. He said in the interview "When being raped, she shouldn’t fight back. She should just be silent and allow the rape. Then they’d have dropped her off after ‘doing her’, and only hit the boy."<ref name=EarlyBBC>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/05/delhi-gang-rape-documentary-airs-early-on-bbc-following-objections | title=Delhi gang-rape documentary airs early on BBC following objections | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=5 March 2015| accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Rawlinson | first=Kevin}}</ref> He later added, "A girl is far more responsible for rape than a boy … A decent girl won’t roam around at nine o’clock at night … Housework and housekeeping is for girls, not roaming in discos and bars at night doing indecent things, wearing indecent clothes."<ref name=Rahman /> A report by the [[Navbharat Times]] has suggested that Mukesh Singh was paid {{currency|40,000|INR}} (about {{currency|420|GBP}}) to do the interview. According to the report, initially he had asked for {{currency|200,000|INR}}, but the amount was negotiated down and the sum was given to his family.<ref name=paid>{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-india-s-daughter-rape-convict-paid-rs40000-for-interview-2066496 |title=India's Daughter: Rape convict paid Rs.40,000 for interview? |author= |date=6 March 2015 |work=[[DNA India]] | |accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref> However, the filmmakers deny that he was paid for the interview.<ref name="isnot">{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/indias-daughters-the-ban-that-actually-isnt/article6975342.ece | title=The ban that actually isn’t | work=[[The Hindu]] | date=10 March 2015 | accessdate=10 March 2015 | author=Hegde, Sanjay}}</ref>
A. P. Singh, a defence lawyer in the case, was shown saying, “If my daughter or sister engaged in pre-marital activities and disgraced herself and allowed herself to lose face and character by doing such things, I would most certainly take this sort of sister or daughter to my farmhouse, and in front of my entire family, I would put petrol on her and set her alight.” Asked later if he stood by those comments, he insisted that he did.<ref name="Independent">{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/indias-daughter-how-india-tried-to-suppress-the-bbc-delhi-gangrape-documentary-10088890.html | title=India's Daughter: How India tried to suppress the BBC Delhi gang-rape documentary | work=[[The Independent]] | date=5 March 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Withnall | first=Adam}}</ref>
==Release== ''India's Daughter'' was given a U.S. theatrical release on October 23, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/meryl-streep-bbc-rape-documentary-832551|title=Meryl Streep: BBC Rape Documentary Banned by India Deserves Oscar|author=Nyay Bhushan|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 16, 2015|accessdate=October 16, 2015}}</ref>
== Reception == The film received a 2015 [[Peabody Award]] as well as positive reviews in the British press, from [[Sonia Faleiro]] in ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/mar/05/indias-daughter-review-this-film-does-what-the-politicians-should-be-doing|title=India's Daughter review – this film does what the politicians should be doing|author=Sonia Faleiro|date=5 Mar 2015|work=The Guardian}}</ref> and [[Yasmin Alibhai-Brown]] in ''[[The Independent]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/this-isnt-an-antifeminist-backlash--its-a-brutal-war-on-women-without-rules-10094485.html|title=This isn’t an anti-feminist backlash – it’s a brutal war on women without rules|date=8 March 2015|work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref>
Some activists have criticised the film. Feminist campaigner [[Kavita Krishnan]], who appears in the film, praised aspects of the film<ref name="nprKrishnan">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/goatsandsoda/2015/03/10/392111392/an-anti-rape-activist-is-disturbed-by-indias-daughter|title=An Anti-Rape Activist Is Disturbed By 'India's Daughter'|work=NPR|date=10 March 2015}}</ref> but stated that the film's title reinforces [[Patriarchy#Feminist theory|patriarchal attitudes]] that Indian women are expected to "behave themselves". She says that the film is part of a wider [[White savior narrative in film|"white saviour"]] mentality. She also said the film failed to profile Indian men who are "on the side of law and order and morality"<ref name="nprKrishnan" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyo.in/politics/kavita-krishnan-nirbhaya-december-16-indias-daughter-leslee-udwin-mukesh-singh-bbc/story/1/2347.html |title=Nirbhaya film: Solidarity is what we want, not a civilising mission |author=Kavita Krishnan |date=3 March 2015 |website= |work=DailyO |accessdate=7 March 2014}}</ref>
[[Meryl Streep]] and [[Freida Pinto]], actresses and ambassadors of ''[[Because I Am a Girl (campaign)|Because I Am a Girl]]'', expressed their support to the director and film.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-others/indias-daughter-gets-support-from-meryl-streep-freida-pinto/ | title=‘India’s Daughter’ gets support from Meryl Streep, Freida Pinto | work=[[The Indian Express]] | publisher=Express News Service | date=8 March 2015 | accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ibtimes.com/bbc-gang-rape-documentary-meryl-streep-attend-us-premiere-indias-daughter-new-york-1839592 | title=BBC Gang-Rape Documentary: Meryl Streep To Attend US Premiere Of 'India's Daughter' In New York | work=[[International Business Times]] | date=8 March 2015 | accessdate=8 March 2015 | author=Varandani, Suman}}</ref> On 9 March, the documentary film screened during an event at [[Baruch College]], [[New York City]], which was attended by [[Meryl Streep]], [[Chris Martin]], [[Dakota Fanning]] and [[Freida Pinto]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2987463/Banned-Indian-rape-documentary-debuts-US-Streep-attends.html | title=Meryl Streep leads the star at US premiere of banned documentary about horrific Indian gang rape | work=[[Mail Online]] | date=10 March 2015 | accessdate=10 March 2015 | author=Carucci, John}}</ref>
The [[U.N. Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]]'s spokesman [[Stéphane Dujarric]] stated on 5 March, "I'm not going to comment on the unspeakable comments that were made by the person accused of raping this girl, but I think the secretary-general has spoken very clearly on the need to halt violence against women and on the need for men to get involved in halting violence against women and decrying it loud and clear every time it occurs."<ref name=BannedinIndia>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/indias-daughter-bbc-documentary-delhi-gang-rape-banned-india-airs-uk-1836750|date=5 Mar 2015|work=International Business Times|first=Suman | last=Varandani|title=India’s Daughter: BBC Documentary On Delhi Gang Rape Banned In India, Airs In The UK}}</ref>
In an interview on 5 March 2015, the parents of the victim said that everybody should watch the documentary.<ref name=SaysFather>{{cite news | url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/everyone-must-see-indias-daughter-says-nirbhayas-father-after-ban-in-india-744411 | title=Everyone Must See 'India's Daughter,' Says Nirbhaya's Father, After Ban in India | work=[[NDTV]] | date=5 March 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Ghosh | first=Deepshikha}}</ref> [[Bollywood]] figures including [[Anushka Sharma]], [[Abhishek Kapoor]], [[Sonal Chauhan]], [[Twinkle Khanna]] and [[Punit Malhotra]] condemned the ban on the same day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/bollywood/nothing-should-be-banned-anushka-sharma-speaks-on-indias-daughter-2145141.html|title=Nothing should be banned: Anushka Sharma speaks on 'India's Daughter'|work=Firstpost|date=10 Mar 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/b-town-slams-governments-ban-on-bbc-documentary-indias-daughter/articleshow/46467920.cms|title=B-Town slams government's ban on BBC documentary 'India's Daughter'|date=5 March 2015|work=[[The Economic Times]]}}</ref>
[[Meenakshi Lekhi]], a [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] spokesperson, alleged that in screening the documentary on [[BBC 4]], a channel dedicated to international arts, music and cultural content, that the makers didn't stick to the stated objective of a "social purpose" and were instead trying to benefit commercially by creating controversies.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Rape-is-a-global-issue-then-why-is-only-India-in-the-spotlight-BJPs-Meenakshi-Lekhi/articleshow/46513189.cms | title=Rape is a global issue, then why is only India in the spotlight | work=[[The Times of India]] | date=10 March 2015 | accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref>
Avanindra Pandey, the friend of the victim who was injured in the attack, said, "The facts are hidden and the content is fake. Only Jyoti and I know what happened on that night and the documentary is far from truth."<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.news18.com/news/india/nirbhayas-friend-who-was-with-her-on-the-fateful-night-calls-indias-daughter-a-fake-film-972447.html | title=Nirbhaya's friend, who was with her on the fateful night, calls the documentary a fake film|work=[[IBNLive]]}}</ref>
== Accolades == ''India's Daughter'' won the ''Best Documentary'' award at the [[San Diego International Film Festival|San Diego Film Festival]] in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sdfilmfest.com/2015awardwinners/|title=San Diego Announces the 2015 Award Winners!|work=San Diego International Film Festival SDiFF|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Ban in India == On 1 March 2015, the film-makers revealed that they had interviewed one of the rapists, when he was being held in the [[Tihar jail]].<ref name=PrisonInterview /><ref name=ThisStory /> The news was picked up by Indian [[news media|media outlets]] soon afterwards.<ref name=ThisStory /><ref name=DuringRape /> The statements made by the convict created public outcry and screening issues in India.<ref name=TwitterOutrage>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/indias-daughter-bbc-four-documentary-provokes-outrage-on-twitter-10086622.html | title=India's Daughter: BBC Four documentary provokes outrage on Twitter | work=[[The Independent]] | date=4 March 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Gander | first=Kashmira}}</ref>
The [[Delhi Police]] filed a [[First Information Report]] (FIR) on 3 March against the filmmakers under Sections 505 (Statements conducing to public mischief), 504 (Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), 505(1)(b) (With intent to cause, or which is likely to cause, fear or alarm to the public), 509 (Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of the [[Indian Penal Code]] and Section 66A of the [[Information Technology Act, 2000]] (Punishment for sending offensive messages through communication service).<ref name=FIRregistered>{{cite news|title=December 16 gangrape convict interview: Delhi Police registers FIR|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/december-16-gangrape-convict-interview-delhi-police-registers-fir/|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=6 March 2015}}</ref> The Deputy Commissioner of Police (Economic Offences Wing) of New Delhi, Rajneesh Garg said, "These excerpts of the interview as published are highly offensive and have already created a situation of tension and fear among women in society. Therefore, in the interest of justice and maintenance of public order, an application was made in court seeking restraining order from publishing, transmitting, uploading and broadcasting the interview."<ref name=Offensivecontent>{{cite news|title=Offensive content: Cops say convict's interview created fear|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/463577/offensive-content-cops-say-convicts.html|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[Deccan Herald]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref>
The Indian government blocked the broadcast in India by obtaining a court order on 4 March 2015. BBC sources said they would comply with the order in India.<ref name="aired" /> In the United Kingdom, however, the BBC broadcast the film on the evening of 4 March.<ref name=BBCForward /> The film was also uploaded to [[YouTube]], and soon went [[viral video|viral]] with several shares on the social media. On 5 March, the Indian government requested that YouTube block the video in India<ref name=YoutubeBlock /> and YouTube complied the same day.<ref name=YoutubeBlocks /> NDTV expressed its silent protest by screening flickering [[Diya (lamp)|lamp]] on a black screen during the scheduled time slot.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-ndtv-runs-blank-screen-to-protest-the-ban-on-india-s-daughter-2067098 | title=NDTV runs blank screen to protest the ban on 'India's Daughter' | work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] | date=8 March 2015 | accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
On 4 March in the [[Indian Parliament]], [[Minister of Home Affairs (India)|Home Minister]] [[Rajnath Singh]] said, "Our government condemns the incident of December 16, 2012 in the strongest possible terms and will not allow any attempt by any individual, group or organisation to leverage such unfortunate incidents for commercial benefit. The respect and dignity of women, constitutes a core value of our culture and tradition. Our government remains fully committed to ensuring safety and dignity of women."<ref name=UdwinLeaves /><ref name=HomeMinRajya>{{cite news|title=Home Minister’s statement on Nirbhaya documentary in Rajya Sabha|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/india/home-minister%E2%80%99s-statement-on-nirbhaya-documentary-in-rajya-sabha_1556766.html|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[Zee News]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Minister of Parliamentary Affairs (India)|Minister of Parliamentary Affairs]] [[M. Venkaiah Naidu]] said in the same debate in the Parliament, "We can ban the documentary in India but there is a conspiracy to defame India and the documentary can be telecast outside. We will also be examining what should be done."<ref name=Dec16Gangrape>{{cite news|title=Dec 16 gangrape: After ban, Nirbhaya documentary ‘India’s Daughter’ aired on BBC; uploaded on YouTube|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/miscellaneous/while-india-bans-bbc-airs-dec-16-nirbhaya-gangrape-documentary-indias-daughter-in-uk/50453/|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[The Financial Express (India)]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> [[Rajya Sabha]] member [[Javed Akhtar]] said, "It's good that this documentary has been made. Crores of men in India have now come to know that they think like a rapist. If it is sounding dirty, they have to think."<ref name=MPsOutraged>{{cite news|title=Nirbhaya case: MPs outraged over interview|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Nirbhaya-case-MPs-outraged-over-interview/articleshow/46462241.cms|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> (A [[crore]] is equal to ten million.)
The film's director, Leslee Udwin, appealed to the [[Indian Prime Minister]], [[Narendra Modi]], to lift the ban in India on 4 March 2015.<ref name=AppealtoModi>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/04/indias-daughter-director-appeals-to-narendra-modi-over-broadcast-ban | title=Delhi rape documentary-maker appeals to Narendra Modi over broadcast ban | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=4 March 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | last=Rahman | first=Maseeh}}</ref>
On 5 March, [[Tihar Jail]] authorities sent a legal notice to the filmmakers. They claimed that the filmmakers had violated the conditions under which they were given permission to film inside the prison. They claimed they had been screened a shorter version of the documentary and also said that they asked the producers to delete the interview with the convict.<ref name=UdwinTihar>{{cite news|title=Tihar Jail sends notice to BBC, director Udwin for breach of conditions|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/delhi/tihar-jail-sends-notice-to-bbc-udwin-for-breach-of-conditions/|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=6 March 2015}}</ref> Udwin denied this saying that she had submitted 16 hours of “raw, unedited footage”, but the review committee told her after watching three hours of it, “We can’t sit through all this, it’s too long.” She said that she then submitted an edited version that was cleared.<ref name=AppealtoModi /> On 5 March Udwin left India, presumably to avoid legal action.<ref name=UdwinLeaves>{{cite news|title=Government turns heat to stop screening of India's Daughter, Leslee Udwin leaves for UK|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-government-turns-heat-to-stop-screening-of-india-s-daughter-leslee-udwin-leaves-for-uk-2066273|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=[[DNA India]]|date=5 March 2015}}</ref>
On 6 March the [[Bar Council of India]] sent a [[Order to show cause|show cause]] notice to the two lawyers, M. L. Sharma and A. P. Singh, who had made [[misogynistic]] statements in the documentary.<ref name=BarCouncilIndia>{{cite news|title=Bar Council of India issues show cause notices to lawyers for anti-women remarks|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/crime/bar-council-of-india-issues-show-cause-notices-to-lawyers-for-anti-women-remarks/|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=7 March 2015}}</ref>
On 7 March [[Najma Heptullah]], the [[Ministry of Minority Affairs|Minority Affairs Minister]], blamed the previous [[United Progressive Alliance|UPA]] government for allowing the film to be made. [[File:IndianolaTXhistoricalmarker.jpg|thumb|State historical marker for Indianola]] [[File:Indianola Texas.jpg|thumb|400px|Indianola by Helmuth Holtz, Sept. 1860]]
'''Indianola''' is a [[ghost town]] located on [[Matagorda Bay]] in [[Calhoun County, Texas|Calhoun County]], [[Texas]], [[United States]]. The community, once the [[county seat]] of Calhoun County, is a part of the [[Victoria, Texas]], [[Victoria metropolitan area|Metropolitan Statistical Area]]. In 1875, the city had a population of 5,000, but on September 15 of that year, a powerful [[tropical cyclone|hurricane]] struck, killing between 150 and 300 and almost entirely destroying the town. Indianola was rebuilt, only to be wiped out on August 19, 1886, by [[Indianola Hurricane of 1886|another intense hurricane]], which was followed by a fire. Indianola was designated a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark]] in 1963, marker number 2642.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indianola, Texas|url=http://www.9key.com/markers/marker_detail.asp?atlas_number=5057002642|work=Recorded Texas Historic Landmark|publisher=William Nienke, Sam Morrow}}</ref>
==History==
===German immigration port of entry=== [[Prince Carl of Solms-Braunfels]], representing the [[Adelsverein]], selected Indian Point in December, 1844 as port of entry for the Verein colonists from [[Germany]]. Prince Solms renamed the port Carlshafen in honor of himself, Count Carl of Castell-Castell<ref>{{cite web|last=Brister|first=Louis E|title=Count Carl of Castell-Castell |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fcaap|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=26 December 2010}}</ref> and Count Victor August of Leiningen-Westerburg-Alt-Leiningen<ref>{{cite web|last=Brister|first=Louis E|title=Count Victor August of Leiningen-Westerburg-Alt-Leiningen |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fle60|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=26 December 2010}}</ref> whom Solms claimed had been christened Carl. Prince Solms' choice of Carlshafen and its inadequate accommodations as a port of entry, as well as the isolated route to New Braunfels, was to keep the Germans from interacting with any Americans.<ref>King (1967) pp.52-58</ref> In February 1845 [[Henry Francis Fisher]] conspired with [[Friedrich Armand Strubberg|Dr. F. Schubbert]] to coerce incoming immigrants to sign legal documents disassociating themselves from the Verein and to join Schubbert's colony in [[Milam County, Texas|Milam County]].<ref>Solms (2000) p.131</ref>{{details|Friedrich Armand Strubberg}}
In May 1846, Meusebach received a letter from Count Castell informing him 4,304 colonists were on their way to Texas. With no funds and no new settlements, the mass of emigrants were stalled at Carlshafen. Meusebach's requests to the Verein for more money, and his warnings at pending bankruptcy for the Verein, brought no results. As a last resort, Meusebach instructed D.H. Klaener to publish the plight in the German news media. Embarrassed by the publicity, the Verein established an inadequate $60,000 letter of credit.<ref>King (1967) pp.75-83</ref> Meusebach had arranged with the Torrey Brothers for transporting the emigrants inland, but the [[United States]] hired the Torrey Brothers for use in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref>King (1967) pp.85,87</ref> An epidemic of [[spinal meningitis]] broke out at Carlshafen and spread with the emigrants to [[New Braunfels, Texas|New Braunfels]] and [[Fredericksburg, Texas|Fredericksburg]].<ref>King (1967) p.88</ref>
Samuel Addition White and William M. Cook founded Indian Point, later Indianola, in August, 1846.<ref name="Indianola, Texas">{{cite web|last=Malsch|first=Brownson|title=Indianola, Texas|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hvi11|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=2 January 2011}}</ref>
Some of these immigrants purchased land from Samuel White and established a settlement at Indian Point. The name of the settlement changed to Indianola in 1849 by combining the word ''Indian'' with ''ola'', the Spanish word for "wave". The German immigrants continued to refer to the community as ''Carlshaven'' (Carl's Harbor) in honor of Prince Carl of Solms-Braunfels.<ref name=wolff>{{cite book|last=Wolff|first=Linda|title=Indianola and Matagorda Island 1837–1887|year=1999|publisher=Eakin Press|location=Austin, Texas|isbn=1-57168-340-2}}</ref>
===Post German immigration years=== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2017}} [[Image:Indianola.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Indianola, Texas in 1875]] From its founding in 1846, Indianola served as a major port, and before the 1875 storm was second only to [[Galveston, Texas|Galveston]] as Texas's primary port.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/mobot31753000247996|title=Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican boundary commission, during the years 1850, '51, '52, and '53 /By John Russell Bartlett, United States commissioner during that period ...|last=Bartlett|first=John Russell|date=1854|publisher=New York and London : D. Appleton & company,|others=Missouri Botanical Garden}}</ref> The town incorporated in 1853. In 1856, the port received cargoes of [[camel]]s, part of the [[US Army Camel Corps]] experiment to replace horses and mules as the primary pack animal in the southwestern parts of the country.
During the [[American Civil War]], Indianola was twice occupied by [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] troops, in October 1862 and November 1863. During the second occupation, part of a Union infantry regiment moving from Indianola to [[Matagorda Island]] [[69th Indiana Infantry drownings|drowned in Matagorda Bay]].
In 1869, the world's first mechanically-refrigerated shipment of beef left Indianola for [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]].
During [[World War II]], the [[U.S. Army]] constructed an anti-aircraft firing range along the Indianola shoreline to train gunners and the facility was used primarily by military personnel from [[Camp Hulen]], located outside of [[Palacios, Texas|Palacios]].
===Impact of storms=== Having survived severe storms before, Indianola was almost totally destroyed [[1875_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Hurricane_Three|on 16 September 1875]]. ''The New York Times'' reported in detail on the extensive loss of life and property. Even the lighthouses were swept away<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|title=The Gulf Cyclone: Additional Particulars Of The Destruction Of Indianola. Hardly A House Left Unharmed|date=September 30, 1875|accessdate=November 9, 2013|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30D15FF385F1A7493C2AA1782D85F418784F9}}</ref> and the [[Lighthouse keeper|keepers]], including Thomas H. Mayne and Edward Flick Jr. of the East Shoal Lighthouse, killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/67362597|title=Thomas Louis Mayne|accessdate=November 9, 2013}}</ref>
The town was rebuilt but events were repeated in 1886. The destruction served as an abject lesson for many residents of [[Galveston]], 100 miles up the Texas coast. However, their calls for a [[seawall]] to protect that city went unheeded, and Galveston nearly shared Indianola's fate when the [[Galveston Hurricane of 1900]] struck the island.
A railroad was intended to connect the port of Indianola to [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]]. After the two storms, discouraged investors abandoned the venture and made Galveston the port of choice. After Galveston's hurricane, shipping traffic recentered over time to inland [[Houston, Texas|Houston]].
After the 1886 storm, the county seat was moved to [[Port Lavaca, Texas|Port Lavaca]]. On October 4, 1887, the post office in Indianola was permanently closed and the town declared "dead".<ref name=wolff /> Today, almost nothing remains of the original Indianola, as, due to storm [[erosion]], most of the site of the city is now under water. A [[granite]] marker was placed on the shore at the nearest point to the Indianola courthouse, now 300 feet (about 90 meters) away in Matagorda Bay. It reads, "Calhoun County Courthouse. Edward Beaumont, Architect 1859. During the Storms of 1875 and 1886, precious lives were saved within its walls of shell, concrete, and lime. Abandoned 1886." The site is also home to a statue of [[René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle]].
Indianola is now the site of a small [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] fishing village.
==Popular culture==
===In literature=== In [[Elizabeth Hand]]'s novel ''Aestival Tide'', a reconstructed Indianola is featured as the lowermost level of the central ziggurat in the dome city of Araboth.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hand, Elizabeth|title=Aestival Tide|edition=Spectra Special Editions|publisher=Spectra|date=August 1, 1992|isbn=978-0-553-29542-9}}</ref>
In the novel ''Matagorda'' by author [[Louis L'Amour]], much of the action took place in Indianola, Texas on the day it was destroyed by the 1875 hurricane. The courthouse, the site of which is now underwater out in the bay, was featured as the last refuge of the townspeople.<ref>{{cite book|title=Matagorda: A Novel|author=L'Amour, Louis|publisher=Bantam|date=February 1, 1985|isbn=978-0-553-28108-8}}</ref>
In Part I of ''[[Isaac's Storm]]'', in the chapter "Galveston: An Absurd Delusion" (pages 79–84), [[Erik Larson (author)|Erik Larson]] describes the two storms that ravaged Indianola and the significance of these storms for [[Galveston, Texas]], leading up to the [[Galveston storm of 1900]].<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Erik Larson (author)|Larson, Erik]]|year=1999|url=http://www.randomhouse.com/features/isaacsstorm/book/index.html|title=Isaac's Storm|publisher=[[Random House]] Publishing|isbn= 0-609-60233-0}}</ref> He notes: "At first, Galveston's leading men seemed to grasp the significance of the Indianola storms. Anyone who looked at a map could see that Galveston was even more vulnerable to destruction than Indianola. It had no picket of barrier islands to shelter it, no buffer of mainland prairie. The city faced the [[Gulf of Mexico|Gulf]] head-on." He further observes: "Six weeks after the second Indianola storm, a group of thirty prominent Galveston residents calling themselves the Progressive Association met and resolved to build a seawall", and "The city's ''Evening Tribune'' endorsed the plan". However, although "The state eventually did authorize a bond to pay for the work," the city's engineer E.M. Hartwick observed, "this was some months after the flood, and by then the attitude was, Oh, we'll never get another one--and they didn't build."
Larson criticizes meteorologist [[Isaac Cline]] (among others) for this failure. For example, Larson cites statements Cline published in the July 1891 Galveston ''News'' article, "West India Hurricanes":<ref>{{cite journal|author=Cline, Isaac M.|title=West India Hurricanes|work=Galveston 'News'|date=July 16, 1891}}</ref> :''If Galveston had any lingering anxiety about its failure to erect a seawall Isaac's 1891 article would have eased them. It was here that he belittled hurricane fears as the artifacts of 'an absurd delusion.' He was especially confident about storm surges. Galveston would escape harm, he argued, because the incoming water would spread first over the vast lowlands ''behind'' Galveston, on the Texas mainland north of the bay where the land was even closer to sea level.
:'' 'It would be impossible,' he wrote, 'for any cyclone to create a storm wave which could materially injure the city.' ''
Further, in Part III of ''Isaac's Storm'', in a chapter titled "Ritter's Cafe: ''You Can't Frighten Me''", Larson publishes the recollections of Mollie Cohen, whose impressions of the Galveston Storm of 1900 reminded her of the second Indianola hurricane: :'' 'We had a storm like this in '86,' Mollie said, referring to the winds and rain that had reached Galveston from the last of the big Indianola hurricanes. 'My father's store on Market Street was flooded,' she said, casually.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Erik Larson (author)|Larson, Erik]]|year=1999|url=http://www.randomhouse.com/features/isaacsstorm/book/index.html|title=Isaac's Storm|publisher=[[Random House]] Publishing|page=157|isbn= 0-609-60233-0}}</ref>
===In music=== {{refimprove|date=June 2012}} Singer/songwriter, [[Charlie Robison]], included a song titled "Indianola" on the 1998 album ''Life of the Party'' that is a specific reference to Indianola, Texas. The song begins from the perspective of a German immigrant approaching Indianola by sea and chronicling details of the narrator's family. The narrator and his cousin attempt to traverse the South to join the [[Union Army]] in the [[American Civil War]], though they encounter Rebel resistance in Indianola, TX. The next scene of the folk song briefly addresses the [[stock market crash of 1929]] in an indirect fashion, noting that little change occurred in their respective lives other than rust's accumulating on wagon wheels. While this verse is brief in regards to words and time, it denotes a subtle and increasing disaffection in the American/Texan experience, adversely affected by seemingly non-relevant incidences. The storyline then progresses to World War II, introducing an internal struggle between the call of duty of the United States of America and its armed conflict with Germany, the ancestral point of origin of many Americans. The overall sentiment of the song begins as a story of new promises followed by a series of fictional, though personally carved facts, that illustrate a common experience for the individualist. Texas exemplifies a spirit that is not only uniquely a Texan story, but an American one, thrusting the individual against the external influence that would assume its right to assert its own values. This, however, should not be confused with contemporary movements deviating from the spirit of this song.
Singer/songwriter [http://www.brianburnsmusic.com/about.php Brian Burns] included the song "Indianola" on his 2004 album "[http://www.brianburnsmusic.com/music.php Heavy Weather]". The [http://www.brianburnsmusic.com/song.php?songinfo=040515 lyrics] of the song chronicle the full life cycle of Indianola with verses from the points of view of a personified Matagorda bay, an immigrant who helped build the city (Johann), a worker who came to help "bury the lost souls who perished that day" (Isaac), and finally the songwriter himself visiting the site (Brian). It is unclear whether the "Johann" mentioned in verse three refers to the Johann Dethardt, the first ship to bring settlers into the area, or Johann Swartz, the owner/builder of the first home erected in what would become Indianola.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txcalhou/indianolatownmarkers.html|title=Town of Indianola Markers|website=www.rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref>
== Education == What is now Indianola is served by the [[Calhoun County Independent School District]].

{{About-distinguish|physical injuries to biological organisms|Major trauma}} {{For|the legal sense of the term|Legal injury}} {{prose|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Injury | synonyms = | image = Xraymachine.JPG | alt = | caption = The [[knee]] of a person is examined with the help of [[radiography]] after an injury. | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Injury''', also known as '''physical trauma''', is damage to the body caused by external force.<ref name=NIH2014>{{cite web|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/woundsandinjuries.html |title=Wounds and Injuries: MedlinePlus |publisher=Nlm.nih.gov |accessdate=2015-07-20}}</ref> This may be caused by accidents, falls, hits, weapons, and other causes.<ref name=NIH2014/> [[Major trauma]] is injury that has the potential to cause prolonged [[disability]] or [[death]].
In 2013, 4.8 million people died from injuries, up from 4.3 million in 1990.<ref name=GDB2013/> More than 30% of these deaths were transport-related injuries.<ref name=GDB2013/> In 2013, 367,000 children under the age of five died from injuries, down from 766,000 in 1990.<ref name=GDB2013>{{cite journal|last1=GBD 2013 Mortality and Causes of Death|first1=Collaborators|title=Global, regional, and national age-sex specific all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 240 causes of death, 1990-2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013|journal=Lancet|date=17 December 2014|pmid=25530442|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)61682-2|pmc=4340604|volume=385|issue=9963|pages=117–71}}</ref> Injuries are the cause of 9% of all deaths, and are the sixth-leading cause of death in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=The top 10 causes of death|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs310/en/index2.html|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Stein2015>{{cite journal|vauthors=Stein DM, Santucci RA |title=An update on urotrauma|journal=Current Opinion in Urology|volume=25|issue=4|pages=323–30|date=July 2015|pmid=26049876|doi=10.1097/MOU.0000000000000184}}</ref>
== Classification == [[File:Injuries world map-Deaths per million persons-WHO2012.svg|thumb|upright=1.3|Deaths from injuries per million persons in 2012 {{refbegin|3}}{{legend|#ffff20|203-358}}{{legend|#ffe820|359-428}}{{legend|#ffd820|429-483}}{{legend|#ffc020|484-559}}{{legend|#ffa020|560-637}}{{legend|#ff9a20|638-716}}{{legend|#f08015|717-817}}{{legend|#e06815|818-939}}{{legend|#d85010|940-1,140}}{{legend|#d02010|1,141-2,961}}{{refend}}]] [[File:Intentional injuries world map-Deaths per million persons-WHO2012.svg|thumb|upright=1.3|Deaths from intentional injuries per million persons in 2012 {{refbegin|3}}{{legend|#ffff20|14-65}}{{legend|#ffe820|66-89}}{{legend|#ffd820|90-114}}{{legend|#ffc020|115-137}}{{legend|#ffa020|138-171}}{{legend|#ff9a20|172-193}}{{legend|#f08015|194-226}}{{legend|#e06815|227-291}}{{legend|#d85010|292-379}}{{legend|#d02010|380-2,730}}{{refend}}]] The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) developed the [[International Classification of External Causes of Injury]] (ICECI). Under this system, injuries are classified by: * mechanism of injury; * objects/substances producing injury; * place of occurrence; * activity when injured; * the role of human intent; and additional modules. These codes allow the identification of distributions of injuries in specific populations and case identification for more detailed research on causes and preventive efforts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/classifications/icd/adaptations/iceci/en/ |title=International Classification of External Causes of Injury (ICECI) |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2014-03-24}}</ref><ref>Robertson, LS (2015) Injury Epidemiology: Fourth Edition. Free online at www.nanlee.net</ref>
The [[United States]] [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] developed the Occupational Injury and Illness Classification System (OIICS). Under this system injuries are classified by * nature, * part of body affected, * source and secondary source, and * event or exposure. The OIICS was first published in 1992 and has been updated several times since.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wwwn.cdc.gov/wisards/oiics/ |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |title=Occupational Injury and Illness Classification System |accessdate=2014-03-24}}</ref>
The Orchard Sports Injury Classification System (OSICS) is used to classify injuries to enable research into specific sports injuries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rae|first1=K|last2=Orchard|first2=J|title=The Orchard Sports Injury Classification System (OSICS) version 10|journal=Clin J Sport Med.|date=May 2007|volume=17|issue=3|pages=201–04|pmid=17513912|doi=10.1097/jsm.0b013e318059b536}}</ref>
=== By cause === * Intentional injury ** [[Suicide]] and [[self-harm]] ** [[Violence]] and [[war]] * [[Accident]]s ** [[Stingray injury]] ** [[Lightning injuries]]
=== By modality === * Traumatic injury, a body [[wound]] or [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]] produced by sudden physical collision or movement<ref name=Dictionary>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Trauma|encyclopedia=Dictionary.com|year=2010|publisher=Dictionary.com, LLC|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/trauma|accessdate=2010-10-31}}</ref> ** [[Avulsion injury]] ** [[Blast injury]] ** [[Bone fracture]] ** [[Internal bleeding]] ** [[Crush injury]] ** [[Needlestick injury]] ** [[Catastrophic injury]] * [[Repetitive strain injury]] or other [[Strain (injury)|strain injury]] * Other injuries from external physical causes, such as [[radiation poisoning]], [[burn]], or [[frostbite]] ** [[Radiation-induced lung injury]] ** [[Microwave burn]] * Injury from [[toxin]] or as adverse effect of a [[pharmaceutical drug]] ** [[Toxic injury]] * Injury from internal causes such as [[reperfusion injury]]
=== By location === * [[Wound]], an injury in which [[skin]] is torn, cut or punctured (an ''open'' wound), or where blunt force [[physical trauma|trauma]] causes a [[bruise|contusion]] (a ''closed'' wound). In [[pathology]], it specifically refers to a sharp injury which damages the [[dermis]] of the skin. * [[Brain injury]] ** [[Acquired brain injury]] ** [[Coup contrecoup injury]] ** [[Diffuse axonal injury]] ** [[Frontal lobe injury]] * [[Nerve injury]] ** [[Spinal cord injury]] ** [[Brachial plexus injury]] ** [[Peripheral nerve injury]] ** [[Sciatic nerve injury]] ** [[Injury of axillary nerve]] * [[Soft tissue injury]] ** [[Penile strangulation]] * [[Cell damage]], including [[direct DNA damage]] * [[Lisfranc injury]] * [[Tracheobronchial injury]] * [[Eye injury]] ** [[Chemical eye injury]] ** [[Eye injuries during general anaesthesia]] * [[Acute kidney injury]] * [[Knee injury]] ** [[Anterior cruciate ligament injury]] ** [[Medial knee injuries]] * [[Back injury]] * [[Hand injury]] * [[Liver injury]] * [[Head injury]] ** [[Penetrating head injury]] ** [[Closed head injury]] * [[Musculoskeletal injury]] ** [[Articular cartilage injuries]] * [[Acute lung injury]] * [[Pancreatic injury]] * [[Thoracic aorta injury]] * [[Biliary injury]] * [[Chest injury]] * [[Asphyxia]]
=== By activity === * [[Reverse bite injury]] * [[Lead climbing injuries]] * [[Occupational injury]] * [[Ventilator-associated lung injury]] * [[Sea urchin injury]] * [[Transfusion-related acute lung injury]] * [[Illness and injuries during spaceflight]]
=== Injury severity score === The [[injury severity score]] (ISS) is a medical score to assess trauma severity.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors = Baker SP, O'Neill B, Haddon W, Long WB | title = The Injury Severity Score: a method for describing patients with multiple injuries and evaluating emergency care | journal = The Journal of Trauma | volume = 14 | pages = 187–96 | publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins | year = 1974 | pmid = 4814394 | issue = 3 | doi=10.1097/00005373-197403000-00001}}</ref><ref name="Copes et al.">{{cite journal | last = Copes | first = W.S. |author2=H.R. Champion |author3=W.J. Sacco |author4=M.M. Lawnick |author5=S.L. Keast |author6=L.W. Bain | title = The Injury Severity Score revisited | journal = The Journal of Trauma | volume = 28 | issue =1 | pages = 69–77 | publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins | year = 1988 | doi = 10.1097/00005373-198801000-00010 | pmid = 3123707}}</ref> It correlates with mortality, morbidity, and hospitalization time after trauma. It is used to define the term ''[[major trauma]]'' ([[polytrauma]]), recognized when the ISS is greater than 15.<ref name="Copes et al." /> The AIS Committee of the [[Association for the Advancement of Automotive Medicine]] designed and updates the scale.

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} '''John Chisholm''', 16th-century Scottish soldier and chief officer, Comptroller and ''Prefect'' of the Scottish artillery for [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] and [[James VI of Scotland]], and keeper of the '''King's Wark''' in Leith. Chisholm was a supporter of Mary, Queen of Scots after her exile in England.
==Career==
===Mary's fireworks=== [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] was eager for Chisholm's arrival as a messenger in Perth in April 1564.<ref>J. H. Pollen ed., ''Papal Negotiations with Mary Queen of Scots'' (SHS, Edinburgh, 1901), p. 450.</ref> As Comptroller of the Royal Artillery for Mary, he received in 1565 the large sum of 10,000 Scottish marks on behalf of the Queen, from the Burgh council of [[Edinburgh]], for the right of superiority of Edinburgh over [[Leith]]. The money was used to take the royal artillery to the west of Scotland during the rebellion called the [[Chaseabout Raid]].<ref>J. Marwick ed., ''Extracts from the Records of the Burgh of Edinburgh, 1557–1571'' (Edinburgh, 1875), p. 228.</ref>
John Chisholm arranged the [[fireworks|firework display]] for the baptism of her son Prince James at [[Stirling Castle]] in December 1566. The preparations were expensive, and John had to send to the Queen twice for extra money. John's account for the event lists his ingredients, including, [[colophony]], [[orpiment]], [[Mercury (element)|quicksilver]], arrows and dozens of small pottery vessels. The fireworks were made in Leith and shipped to [[Stirling]] in great secrecy, being carried to the castle at the dead of night "for feir of knowledge thairof." John also arranged the making of costumes used in a pageant of an assault on a mock castle.<ref>''Accounts of the Treasurer of Scotland'' vol.12 (1970), pp. 58 and 403–9.</ref>
===King's Wark in Leith=== {{Infobox military structure | name= King's Wark | location = Leith, Scotland | image = The King's Wark, Shore Leith.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Site of the '''King's Wark''' Royal Arsenal | pushpin_map = Scotland | coordinates = {{coord|55.9761|-3.1695|type:landmark|display=inline}} | type = | built = in royal occupation since 1434 | builder = | used = disused as arsenal since 1647 | battles = [[Burning of Edinburgh (1544)|destroyed May 1544]] | past_commanders = John Chisholm (1564-1606) }} In April 1567 [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] confirmed in [[Parliament of Scotland|Parliament]] John Chisholm's possession of the King's Wark in Leith,<ref>[http://www.rps.ac.uk/trans/1567/4/15 ''The Records of the Parliaments of Scotland to 1707'', K.M. Brown et al eds (St Andrews, 2007-2013) Retrieved: 3 March 2013.]</ref> which he had held in ''feu'' since May 1564.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=w4MvAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Robertson, David, ''The Sculptured Stones of Leith'', (1851)], p.67 citing charter in City archives.</ref> There, John was in charge of the long established Shore-side arsenal which served the [[Royal Scots Navy]]. The arsenal had been founded by [[James I of Scotland]] in 1434. The buildings, which included a tower had been burnt in May 1544 during the war of the [[Rough Wooing]] after 80,000 cannonballs were [[Burning of Edinburgh (1544)|looted by the English army]].<ref>Patten, William, in ''Tudor Tracts'', (1903), p. 44.</ref> In 1545 [[Robert Logan of Restalrig]] used the tower as a [[Tolbooth]] for Leith.<ref>[http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/51945/details/edinburgh+leith+the+shore+king+s+wark/ RCAHMS Canmore database: King's Wark]</ref> Now demolished, the tower was depicted in a drawing by [[John Slezer]] in 1693.<ref>[http://www.capitalcollections.org.uk/index.php?a=ViewItem&i=440&WINID=1362442350460 Slezer drawings, Edinburgh City Collection]</ref> The site is now a bar and restaurant.
[[Anne of Denmark]] arrived in Scotland on 1 May 1590 with James VI, and stayed five nights in the King's Wark.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland, vol. 10, (Edinburgh, 1936), 863.</ref> The path from the ship to their throne room in Chisholm's house was strewn with [[Scottish Royal tapestry collection|tapestry]].<ref>Stevenson, David, ''Scotland's Last Royal Wedding'', (1985), pp. 100 and 139: [https://archive.org/stream/papersrelativeto00crairich#page/n69/mode/2up ''Papers Relative to the Marriage of James VI'', (1828) pp.37-8]: [https://archive.org/stream/memoirsaffairss01denngoog#page/n122/mode/2up Moysie, David, ''Memoirs of the Affairs of Scotland'', (1830), p. 83].</ref> The ceremony of the reception at Leith and the King's Wark had been carefully planned the previous September. A special wooden stair was built for her to enter directly into the first-floor hall. There were chairs for Anne and James VI on this "scaffold", where they sat in public and listened to a speech of welcome called an oration or "harangue," made by [[James Elphinstone, 1st Lord Balmerino|James Elphinstone]] in French. The directions included the order of entry, seating, and even where people should look. Once Anne was in the King's Wark, the scaffold was taken away, and the people of Leith were ordered to unload any guns and forbidden to mend ships on the Shore until she left.<ref>[[Thomas Napier Thomson|Thomson, Thomas]], ed., [https://books.google.com/books?id=cGALAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''David Calderwood's History of Kirk of Scotland'', vol. 5 (1844)], pp. 60–64, 94. (James Elphinstone also had a house on the Shore in Leith, "Balmerino's House".)</ref>
The buildings passed to Bernard Lindsay of Lochhill in 1606 by Act of Parliament. Bernard Lindsay, a chamber servant of James VI, was required to reserve a cellar for storing wines for the King's use.<ref>''Acts of the Parliaments of Scotland'', vol.4 (1816), p.315</ref> He also added a [[royal tennis|tennis court]]. As a courtier Lindsay had brought [[Henry Wotton]] to James VI at [[Dunfermline Palace]] in 1601, when Wotton was masquerading as an Italian "Octavio Baldi".<ref>''CSP. Scotland'', vol. 13 (HMSO 1969), p. 876: H. Wotton, ''Reliquiae Wottonianae'' (London 1654), 29–35.</ref> In preparation for James's "salmonlike" return to Scotland in 1617, cannon wheels and stocks were kept there, and in 1623 the [[Master of Work to the Crown of Scotland|Master of Work]], [[James Murray (architect)|James Murray of Kilbaberton]] stored cannon and shot from a Dunkirk ship in Bernard Lindsay's Close.<ref>Imrie & Dunbar, ed., ''Accounts of the Master's of Work'', vol. 2, HMSO, Edinburgh (1882), pp. 81, 157 and 159.</ref> It is thought that Bernard Street takes its name from Lindsay of Lochhill. In 1647 the site was acquired by Edinburgh burgh council from William Dick of Braid.<ref>Wood, Marguerite, ed., ''Extracts Burgh Records Edinburgh, 1604-1624'', (1931), p.376: [https://books.google.com/books?id=caIJAAAAIAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Tales, Traditions, & Antiquities of Leith'' (1865)], pp. 36–38.</ref>
===Adversity=== John Chisholm was appointed Prefect and "Second Person" of the royal artillery of Scotland (S. D. N. Regis Machinarii Bellitarii Prefecti) on 23 August 1569, during the Regency of the [[Regent Moray|James Stewart, Earl of Moray]].<ref>''Register of the Great Seal of Scotland'', vol. 6 (1963), p. 141, no. 723.</ref> In 1570, Chisholm joined [[William Kirkcaldy of Grange]] in the garrison of [[Edinburgh Castle]] that remained loyal to [[Mary, Queen of Scots]]. During the following 'Lang Siege' of the Castle and [[Marian civil war]], Chisholm travelled abroad seeking support and supplies. In February 1571 he was in London and wrote about ongoing peace negotiations, hoping that [[Elizabeth I of England]] would act to restore Mary to the Scottish throne. He hoped that the frustrating talks would be concluded soon; "I hoip seurlie within sax ouilkis (six weeks), we salbe at our wittis end and sooner."
Chisholm visited Mary at [[Sheffield Castle]], and took letters to France in April, borrowing £3 from [[John Lesley]], [[Bishop of Ross (Scotland)|Bishop of Ross]]. The Bishop kept a note of Chisholm's movements; he returned to Scotland from Dieppe in June 1571, carrying money sent by the exiled [[James Beaton (archbishop of Glasgow)|Bishop of Glasgow]], cannonballs of four different calibres and [[pike (weapon)|pikes]]. These supplies were obtained from [[Charles IX of France]].<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/correspondancedi00feneuoft#page/203/mode/1up ''Correspondance Diplomatique De Bertrand De Salignac De La Mothe Fenelon'', vol. 4, Paris (1840), pp. 203–4.]</ref> Chisholm and his ship were captured at [[North Queensferry]] in July by [[Patrick Lindsay, 6th Lord Lindsay|Patrick, Lord Lindsay]], but he managed to pass some of the money to Mary's supporters. It was thought he had intended to take [[Tantallon Castle]], linking up with Mary's supporters who unsuccessfully attacked the castle on 2 July 1571.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 3 (1903), pp. 478–80, 485–87, 529, 532–33, 535, 620–21, 623–24 and 636.</ref>
Chisholm was allowed to return to France and joined the Bishop of Glasgow. In March 1573 [[William Maitland of Lethington]] thought his adversaries had discovered the key to the cipher code he used in his letters when James Kirkcaldy was captured. He used John Chisholm's code in a letter to the Bishop. Agents of the English Secretary of State, [[William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley|William Cecil]], intercepted and easily decoded this letter.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 4 (1905), p. 523, no. 586.</ref> John wrote to Mary, Queen of Scots from Paris in August 1575. He asked that he might come to England and serve in her household with his wife, and concluded his letter with his hopes of Mary's "suddane" delivery from her troubles.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol.5 (1907), pp. 158–60, no. 167.</ref>
===Rehabilitation=== After this period of exile,<ref>''Accounts of the Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 12 (1970), p. 379.</ref> in July 1576 Chisholm gained an official pardon for his support of Mary and Grange and unauthorized travel abroad. On 31 May 1579 he was re-appointed as "Comptroller and Second Person of the Artillery and Munition within all parts of Scotland."<ref>''Register of the Privy Council of Scotland'', vol. 7, HMSO Edinburgh (1966), p. 97, no. 659, and pp. 312–13, no. 1909.</ref> The gift of the King's Wark, "Opus Regium," was confirmed in May 1588, giving his title as; ''Compotorus Rotulatori Tormentorum Bellicorum'' – Controller of the accounting rolls for war machines.<ref>''Register of the Great Seal of Scotland, 1580–93'', (1888), pp. 529–30, no. 1547.</ref>
The French Ambassador [[Bertrand de Salignac de la Mothe-Fénelon]] noted that Chisholm was still active as a supporter of Mary in February 1583, and Chisholm asked that Mary should continue paying him a pension. In May 1583 The English diplomat [[Robert Bowes (diplomat)|Robert Bowes]] reported him as a "notorious instrument" for Maineville, the agent of the [[Esmé Stewart, 1st Duke of Lennox]] who was expelled from Scotland by the [[Raid of Ruthven|Gowrie Regime]].<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 6 (1910), pp. 312, 375, 441 and 449.</ref>

Jesse Eslinger | studio = | distributor = [[Invisible Children, Inc.]] | released = {{Film date|2012|3|5|Internet}} | runtime = 30 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }}{{LRA}} '''''Kony 2012''''' is a short documentary film produced by [[Invisible Children, Inc.]] (authors of ''[[Invisible Children]]''). It was released on March 5, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltvbc.com/video/trending+now+kony+2012/video.html?v=2206826267#stories/video|title=News Hour – Trending Now: Kony 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2012|date=March 6, 2012|publisher=[[Global TV]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.news.ninemsn.com.au/world/8431277/kony-2012-sheds-light-on-uganda-conflict|title=Kony 2012 sheds light on Uganda conflict|date=March 7, 2012|publisher=Ninemsn|accessdate=March 7, 2012|author1=Lees, Philippa |author2=Zavan, Martin }}{{cite news|url=http://post-journal.com/page/content.detail/id/599038/Jackson-Center-To-Show-KONY-2012.html?nav=5004|title=Jackson Center To Show KONY2012|date=February 14, 2012|publisher=[[The Post-Journal]]|accessdate=March 7, 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17295078|title=Uganda rebel Joseph Kony target of viral campaign video|date=March 8, 2012|publisher=BBC News}} The film's purpose was to promote the charity's "Stop Kony" movement to make Ugandan cult and militia leader, indicted war criminal and the [[International Criminal Court]] fugitive [[Joseph Kony]] globally known in order to have him arrested by the end of 2012,{{cite news|url=http://kykernel.com/2012/03/07/a-call-for-justice/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713191826/http://kykernel.com/2012/03/07/a-call-for-justice/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 13, 2012 |title=A call for justice |date=March 7, 2012 |last=Myers |first=Julia |publisher=Kentucky Kernel }} when the campaign expired. The film spread [[viral video|virally]] and the campaign was initially supported by various celebrities.{{cite web|url=http://www.theyorker.co.uk/news/citynews/10807 |title=Kony fever hits York! |accessdate=March 7, 2012 |date=March 7, 2012 |work=The Yorker |author=Neylon, Stephanie |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308142114/http://www.theyorker.co.uk/news/citynews/10807 |archivedate=March 8, 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/tech/892373-kony-2012-campaign-shedding-light-on-uganda-conflict-a-huge-online-success|title=Kony 2012: Campaign Shedding light on Uganda Conflict a Huge Online Success |accessdate=March 7, 2012|date=March 7, 2012|work=[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]|author=Molloy, Mark}}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/03/07/kony-2012-invisible-children-documentary-sheds-light-on-uganda-conflict-video_n_1326183.html?ref=uk|title=Kony 2012: Invisible Children Documentary Sheds Light On Uganda Conflict |accessdate=March 7, 2012|date=March 7, 2012|work=[[Huffington Post]]|author= Nelson, Sara C.}} {{as of|2017|10|10|df=US}}, the film has received over 101 million views and nearly 1.4 million "likes" on the video-sharing website [[YouTube]],{{cite web|title=KONY 2012|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4MnpzG5Sqc|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=March 2, 2014}} and over 18.6 million views and over 21.5 thousand "likes" on [[Vimeo]],{{cite web|url=http://vimeo.com/37119711|title=Kony 2012|publisher=Vimeo |accessdate=May 5, 2012 }} with other views on a central "Kony 2012" website operated by Invisible Children. The intense exposure of the video caused the "Kony 2012" website to crash shortly after it began gaining widespread popularity.{{cite web|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8431494 |title=Australian support amasses for Kony 2012 |accessdate=March 7, 2012 |date=March 7, 2012 |work=ninemsn |author=Lees, Philippa |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309174352/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8431494 |archivedate=March 9, 2012 }} A poll suggested that more than half of young adult Americans heard about ''Kony 2012'' in the days following the video's release.[http://pewinternet.org/Reports/2012/Kony-2012-Video/Main-report.aspx Rainie, Lee, Paul Hitlin, Mark Jurkowitz, Michael Dimock, Shawn Neidorf. The viral Kony 2012 video. Pew Internet & American Life Report. March 15, 2012]{{cite news|author1=Polly Curtis |author2=Tom McCarthy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/reality-check-with-polly-curtis/2012/apr/20/kony-2012-what-happens-next |title=Kony 2012: what happens next?|work=The Guardian |accessdate=April 22, 2012 |date=April 20, 2012}} It was included among the top international events of 2012 by [[PBS]]{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/multimedia/world122412/6.html |title=Memorable World Moments of 2012 | PBS NewsHour | Dec. 24, 2012 |publisher=PBS |date=December 24, 2012 |accessdate=October 16, 2013}} and called the most viral video ever by ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''.{{cite news|last=Carbone |first=Nick |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2012/12/04/top-10-arts-lists/slide/kony-2012/ |title=Kony 2012 | Arts & Entertainment | TIME.com |publisher=Entertainment.time.com |date=December 4, 2012 |accessdate=October 16, 2013}} The campaign resulted in a resolution by the [[United States Senate]] and contributed to the decision to send troops by the [[African Union]]. The film also called for an April 20 world wide canvassing campaign, called "Cover the Night". On April 5, 2012, Invisible Children released a follow-up video, titled ''[[#Kony 2012 Part II|Kony 2012: Part II – Beyond Famous]]'', which failed to repeat the success of the original. ==''Kony 2012''== The film documents the [[Invisible Children, Inc.|Invisible Children]]'s plans and efforts to capture [[Joseph Kony]]. It describes Kony's actions with his rebel militia group [[Lord's Resistance Army]] (LRA), including [[Impressment|forced recruitment]] of [[child soldiers]], and the regions (northern [[Uganda]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] and [[South Sudan]]) in which they have been active.{{cite web|url=http://www.altoona.psu.edu/now/news.php?value=3646 |title=KONY 2012, an Invisible Children film, to show on campus March 12 |accessdate=March 7, 2012 |date=March 5, 2012 |publisher=[[Penn State Altoona]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310034444/http://www.altoona.psu.edu/now/news.php?value=3646 |archivedate=March 10, 2012 }} One of the main people featured in the film is a young Ugandan named Jacob Avaye, whose brother was killed by the LRA. In response, director and founder of Invisible Children, [[Jason Russell]], promises Jacob that he will help "stop Kony".{{cite news |title=Celebs Help 'Stop Kony' Trend on Twitter: Who Is Kony? |author=Jenny McGrath |url=http://www.wetpaint.com/network/articles/celebs-help-stop-kony-tweet-on-twitter-who-is-kony |newspaper=[[Wetpaint]] |date=March 7, 2012 |accessdate=March 7, 2012}} The film advocates the restoration of social order and curtailing compelled and coerced [[Military use of children|youth military service]].
